**Ljubljana** ^[\[a\]](#cite_note-15)^ (also known by other [historical names](#Name)) is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and largest city of [Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia "Slovenia"),^[\[15\]](#cite_note-Portrait20102-16)^^[\[16\]](#cite_note-GV52-22-17)^ located along a trade route between the northern [Adriatic Sea](/wiki/Adriatic_Sea "Adriatic Sea") and the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") region,^[\[17\]](#cite_note-Mehle_Mihovec-18)^ north of [the country's largest marsh](/wiki/Ljubljana_Marsh "Ljubljana Marsh"), inhabited since prehistoric times. It is the country's cultural, educational, economic, political and administrative center and the seat of [Urban Municipality of Ljubljana](/wiki/Urban_Municipality_of_Ljubljana "Urban Municipality of Ljubljana").{#cite_ref-Mehle_Mihovec_18-0}

During antiquity, a [Roman](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") city called [Emona](/wiki/Emona "Emona") stood in the area.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)^ The city was first mentioned in the first half of the [12th century](/wiki/12th_century "12th century"). It was the historical capital of [Carniola](/wiki/Carniola "Carniola"),^[\[17\]](#cite_note-Mehle_Mihovec-18)^ one of the [Slovene](/wiki/Slovenes "Slovenes")-inhabited parts of the [Habsburg monarchy](/wiki/Habsburg_monarchy "Habsburg monarchy").^[\[15\]](#cite_note-Portrait20102-16)^ It was under [Habsburg](/wiki/House_of_Habsburg "House of Habsburg") rule from the Middle Ages until the dissolution of the [Austro-Hungarian](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary") Empire in 1918. After [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), Ljubljana became the capital of the [Socialist Republic of Slovenia](/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Slovenia "Socialist Republic of Slovenia"), part of the [Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia"). The city retained this status until Slovenia became independent in 1991 and Ljubljana became the capital of the newly formed state.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-STAT112-20)^{#cite_ref-STAT112_20-0}  

Name {#Name}
------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Name")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Valvasor_1689_Ljubljana_lintvern.jpg/220px-Valvasor_1689_Ljubljana_lintvern.jpg)](/wiki/File:Valvasor_1689_Ljubljana_lintvern.jpg) Depiction of the city's coat of arms featuring the [dragon](/wiki/Saint_George_and_the_Dragon "Saint George and the Dragon") on top of the [castle](/wiki/Ljubljana_Castle "Ljubljana Castle"), from [Valvasor](/wiki/Valvasor "Valvasor")'s *[The Glory of the Duchy of Carniola](/wiki/The_Glory_of_the_Duchy_of_Carniola "The Glory of the Duchy of Carniola")*, 1689

The exact origin of the name *Ljubljana* is unclear. In [medieval times](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"), both the river and the town were also called *Laibach* (
German: [\[ˈlaɪbax\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Standard_German "Help:IPA/Standard German") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/dd/De-Laibach.ogg/De-Laibach.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:De-Laibach.ogg "File:De-Laibach.ogg")^) in German. This name was used within the region until 1918 and continues to be used in German. In Italian, the city is referred to as *[Lubiana](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lubiana "it:Lubiana")* , and in [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin"), it is known as *Labacum* .^[\[20\]](#cite_note-21)^{#cite_ref-21}

The German name was first documented in 1144, and the Slovenian form appeared in records as early as 1146. The 10th-century work "Life of Gregentios" provides the Greek variant Λυπλιανές (*Lyplianes* ) and situates it among the [Avars](/wiki/Pannonian_Avars "Pannonian Avars") in the 6th century. This account is influenced by an earlier northern Italian source written shortly after the [conquest of 774](/wiki/Siege_of_Pavia_(773%E2%80%93774) "Siege of Pavia (773–774)").^[\[21\]](#cite_note-22)^{#cite_ref-22}

The connection between the Slovene and German names has posed a puzzle for scholars. In 2007, linguist [Tijmen Pronk](/wiki/Tijmen_Pronk "Tijmen Pronk"), an authority in comparative Indo-European linguistics and Slovene dialectology from the [University of Leiden](/wiki/University_of_Leiden "University of Leiden"), provided strong support for the theory that the Slavic *ljub-* 'to love, like' was the most likely origin. He argued that the river's name likely stemmed from the settlement's name.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-23)^^[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)^ Silvo Torkar, a linguist with expertise in Slovene names, put forth the idea that Ljubljana's name has its roots in *Ljubija* , the original name of the [Ljubljanica River](/wiki/Ljubljanica "Ljubljanica"). This can be traced back to the Old Slavic male name *Ljubovid* , which translates to 'the one with a lovely appearance'. Torkar also asserted that the name *Laibach* is a combination of German and Slovene, sharing its origins with the same personal name.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-25)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-26)^{#cite_ref-26}  

Dragon symbol {#Dragon_symbol}
------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Dragon symbol")\]

The city's symbol is the [Ljubljana Dragon](/wiki/Ljubljana_Dragon "Ljubljana Dragon"). It is depicted on the top of the tower of [Ljubljana Castle](/wiki/Ljubljana_Castle "Ljubljana Castle") in the Ljubljana coat of arms and on the Ljubljanica-crossing [Dragon Bridge](/wiki/Dragon_Bridge_(Ljubljana) "Dragon Bridge (Ljubljana)") (*Zmajski most*).^[\[26\]](#cite_note-ARCH1242-27)^ It represents power, courage, and greatness.{#cite_ref-ARCH1242_27-0}

Several explanations describe the origin of the Ljubljana Dragon. According to a [Slavic](/wiki/Slavic_mythology "Slavic mythology") myth, the slaying of a dragon releases the waters and ensures the fertility of the earth, and it is thought that the myth is tied to the [Ljubljana Marsh](/wiki/Ljubljana_Marsh "Ljubljana Marsh"), the expansive marshy area that periodically threatens Ljubljana with flooding.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Exhib_20102-28)^ According to [Greek legend](/wiki/Greek_mythology "Greek mythology"), the [Argonauts](/wiki/Argonauts "Argonauts") on their return home after having taken the [Golden Fleece](/wiki/Golden_Fleece "Golden Fleece") found a large lake surrounded by a marsh between the present-day towns of [Vrhnika](/wiki/Vrhnika "Vrhnika") and Ljubljana. There [Jason](/wiki/Jason "Jason") struck down a monster. This monster evolved into the [dragon](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon") that today is present in the city coat of arms and flag.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-InfoDragon2-29)^{#cite_ref-InfoDragon2_29-0}

It is historically more believable that the dragon was adopted from [Saint George](/wiki/Saint_George "Saint George"), the patron of the Ljubljana Castle chapel built in the 15th century. In the legend of Saint George, the dragon represents the old ancestral [paganism](/wiki/Paganism "Paganism") overcome by [Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"). According to another explanation, related to the second, the dragon was at first only a decoration above the city coat of arms. In the [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque"), it became part of the coat of arms and, in the 19th and especially the 20th century, it outstripped the tower and other elements in importance.  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: History")\]  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Ljubljana](/wiki/Timeline_of_Ljubljana "Timeline of Ljubljana").  

### Prehistory {#Prehistory}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Prehistory")\]

Around 2000 BC, the Ljubljana Marsh was settled by people living in [pile dwellings](/wiki/Stilt_house "Stilt house"). [Prehistoric pile dwellings](/wiki/Prehistoric_pile_dwellings_around_the_Alps "Prehistoric pile dwellings around the Alps") and [the oldest wooden wheel in the world](/wiki/Ljubljana_Marshes_Wooden_Wheel "Ljubljana Marshes Wooden Wheel")^[\[29\]](#cite_note-30)^ are among the most notable archeological findings from the marshland. These lake-dwelling people survived through hunting, fishing and primitive agriculture. To get around the marshes, they used [dugout canoes](/wiki/Dugout_canoe "Dugout canoe") made by cutting out the inside of tree trunks. Their archaeological remains, nowadays in the [Municipality of Ig](/wiki/Municipality_of_Ig "Municipality of Ig"), have been designated a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site") since June 2011, in the [common nomination of six Alpine states](/wiki/Prehistoric_pile_dwellings_around_the_Alps "Prehistoric pile dwellings around the Alps").^[\[30\]](#cite_note-31)^^[\[31\]](#cite_note-32)^{#cite_ref-32}

Later, the area remained a transit point, for groups including the [Illyrians](/wiki/Illyrians "Illyrians"), followed by a mixed nation of the [Celts](/wiki/Celts "Celts") and the Illyrians called the [Iapodes](/wiki/Iapodes "Iapodes"), and then in the 3rd century BC a Celtic tribe, the [Taurisci](/wiki/Taurisci "Taurisci").^[\[32\]](#cite_note-Histo12-33)^{#cite_ref-Histo12_33-0}  

### Antiquity {#Antiquity}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Antiquity")\]  
Main article: [Emona](/wiki/Emona "Emona")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Emona3.JPG/220px-Emona3.JPG)](/wiki/File:Emona3.JPG) Excavations at the building site of the planned new [National and University Library of Slovenia](/wiki/National_and_University_Library_of_Slovenia "National and University Library of Slovenia"). One of the discoveries was an ancient Roman public bath house.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-Zupanek_20102-34)^

Around 50 BC, the [Romans](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") built a military encampment that later became a permanent settlement called [Iulia Aemona](/wiki/Emona "Emona").^[\[34\]](#cite_note-Histo22-35)^^[\[35\]](#cite_note-roman_emona2-36)^^[\[36\]](#cite_note-legacy2-37)^ This entrenched fort was occupied by the *[Legio XV Apollinaris](/wiki/Legio_XV_Apollinaris "Legio XV Apollinaris")* .^[\[37\]](#cite_note-Apollinaris2-38)^ In 452, it was destroyed by the [Huns](/wiki/Huns "Huns") under [Attila](/wiki/Attila_the_Hun "Attila the Hun")'s orders,^[\[34\]](#cite_note-Histo22-35)^ and later by the [Ostrogoths](/wiki/Ostrogoths "Ostrogoths") and the [Lombards](/wiki/Lombards "Lombards").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-Artis2-39)^ Emona housed 5,000 to 6,000 inhabitants and played an important role during battles. Its plastered brick houses, painted in different colours, were connected to a [drainage system](/wiki/Sewage "Sewage").^[\[34\]](#cite_note-Histo22-35)^{#cite_ref-Histo22_35-2}

In the 6th century, the ancestors of the [Slovenes](/wiki/Slovenes "Slovenes") moved in. In the 9th century, they fell under [Frankish](/wiki/Franks "Franks") domination, while experiencing frequent [Magyar](/wiki/Hungarian_people "Hungarian people") raids.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Histo62-40)^ Not much is known about the area during the settlement of [Slavs](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") in the period between the downfall of Emona and the Early Middle Ages.{#cite_ref-Histo62_40-0}  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]

The parchment sheet *Nomina defunctorum* ("Names of the Dead"), most probably written in the second half of 1161, mentions the nobleman Rudolf of Tarcento, a lawyer of the [Patriarchate of Aquileia](/wiki/Patriarchate_of_Aquileia_(Episcopal) "Patriarchate of Aquileia (Episcopal)"), who had bestowed a canon with 20 farmsteads beside the [castle of Ljubljana](/wiki/Ljubljana_Castle "Ljubljana Castle") (*castrum Leibach* ) to the Patriarchate. According to the historian [Peter Štih](/wiki/Peter_%C5%A0tih "Peter Štih")'s deduction, this happened between 1112 and 1125, the earliest mention of Ljubljana.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-CL2-41)^{#cite_ref-CL2_41-0}

The property changed hands repeatedly until the first half of the 12th century. The territory south of the [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") where Ljubljana developed, gradually became property of the Carinthian Dukes of the [House of Sponheim](/wiki/House_of_Sponheim "House of Sponheim").^[\[40\]](#cite_note-CL2-41)^ Urban settlement started in the second half of the 12th century.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-CL2-41)^ At around 1200, [market rights](/wiki/Market_town "Market town") were granted to Old Square (*Stari trg*),^[\[41\]](#cite_note-Ljubljana_Town_Hall2-42)^ which at the time was one of Ljubljana's three original districts. The other two districts were an area called "Town" (*Mesto*), built around the predecessor of the present-day [Ljubljana Cathedral](/wiki/Ljubljana_Cathedral "Ljubljana Cathedral") at one side of the [Ljubljanica](/wiki/Ljubljanica "Ljubljanica") River, and New Square (*Novi trg*) at the other side.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-AVLuwigana2-43)^ The [Franciscan Bridge](/wiki/Franciscan_Bridge "Franciscan Bridge"), a predecessor of the present-day [Triple Bridge](/wiki/Triple_Bridge "Triple Bridge"), and the [Butchers' Bridge](/wiki/Cobblers%27_Bridge#History "Cobblers' Bridge") connected the walled areas with wooden buildings.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-AVLuwigana2-43)^ Ljubljana acquired the [town privileges](/wiki/Town_privileges "Town privileges") at some time between 1220 and 1243.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-44)^ Seven fires erupted during the Middle Ages.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-45)^ Artisans organised themselves into [guilds](/wiki/Guild "Guild"). The [Teutonic Knights](/wiki/Teutonic_Knights "Teutonic Knights"), the [Conventual Franciscans](/wiki/Conventual_Franciscans "Conventual Franciscans"), and the [Franciscans](/wiki/Franciscans "Franciscans") settled there.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-46)^ In 1256, when the Carinthian duke [Ulrich III of Spanheim](/wiki/Ulrich_III,_Duke_of_Carinthia "Ulrich III, Duke of Carinthia") became lord of Carniola, the provincial capital was moved from [Kamnik](/wiki/Kamnik "Kamnik") to Ljubljana.{#cite_ref-46}

In the late 1270s, Ljubljana was conquered by King [Ottokar II of Bohemia](/wiki/Ottokar_II_of_Bohemia "Ottokar II of Bohemia").^[\[46\]](#cite_note-MunicipalityHistory2-47)^ In 1278, after Ottokar's defeat, it became---together with the rest of [Carniola](/wiki/Carniola "Carniola")---property of [Rudolph of Habsburg](/wiki/Rudolph_I_of_Germany "Rudolph I of Germany").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-Artis2-39)^^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Histo62-40)^ It was administered by the [Counts of Gorizia](/wiki/Counts_of_Gorizia "Counts of Gorizia") from 1279 until 1335,^[\[41\]](#cite_note-Ljubljana_Town_Hall2-42)^^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^^[\[48\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhillips1911-49)^ when it became the capital town of Carniola.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Histo62-40)^ Renamed *Laibach* , it was owned by the [House of Habsburg](/wiki/House_of_Habsburg "House of Habsburg") until 1797.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-Artis2-39)^ In 1327, the Ljubljana's "[Jewish Quarter](/wiki/Jewish_quarter_(diaspora) "Jewish quarter (diaspora)")"---now only "Jewish Street" (*Židovska ulica*) remains---was established with a synagogue, and lasted until Emperor [Maximilian I](/wiki/Maximilian_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor") in 1515 and expelled the Jews from Ljubljana at the request of its citizens, for which he demanded a certain payment from the town.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-Ljubljana_Town_Hall2-42)^ In 1382, in front of [St. Bartholomew's Church](/wiki/St._Bartholomew%27s_Church_(Ljubljana) "St. Bartholomew's Church (Ljubljana)") in [Šiška](/wiki/Spodnja_%C5%A0i%C5%A1ka "Spodnja Šiška"), at the time a nearby village, now part of Ljubljana, a peace treaty was signed between the [Republic of Venice](/wiki/Republic_of_Venice "Republic of Venice") and [Leopold III](/wiki/Leopold_III_of_Austria_(Habsburg) "Leopold III of Austria (Habsburg)") of [Habsburg](/wiki/Habsburg "Habsburg").^[\[41\]](#cite_note-Ljubljana_Town_Hall2-42)^{#cite_ref-Ljubljana_Town_Hall2_42-3}  

### Early modern {#Early_modern}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Early modern")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Ljubljana-Valvasor.jpg/660px-Ljubljana-Valvasor.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ljubljana-Valvasor.jpg) "Laybach" (Ljubljana) in [Johann Weikhard von Valvasor's](/wiki/Johann_Weikhard_von_Valvasor "Johann Weikhard von Valvasor") work *[The Glory of the Duchy of Carniola](/wiki/The_Glory_of_the_Duchy_of_Carniola "The Glory of the Duchy of Carniola")* of 1689

In the 15th century, Ljubljana became recognised for its art, particularly painting and sculpture. The [Latin Catholic](/wiki/Latin_Church "Latin Church") [Archdiocese of Ljubljana](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Ljubljana "Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Ljubljana") was established in 1461 and the [Church of St. Nicholas](/wiki/Ljubljana_Cathedral "Ljubljana Cathedral") became the diocesan cathedral.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Histo62-40)^ After the [1511 Idrija earthquake](/wiki/1511_Idrija_earthquake "1511 Idrija earthquake"),^[\[49\]](#cite_note-bavec2-50)^^[\[50\]](#cite_note-Lipold2-51)^^[\[51\]](#cite_note-Fitzko2-52)^^[\[52\]](#cite_note-Cunningham2-53)^ the city was rebuilt in the [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture") style and a new wall was built around it.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-Histo32-54)^ Wooden buildings were forbidden after a large fire at New Square in 1524.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-55)^^[\[55\]](#cite_note-56)^{#cite_ref-56}

In the 16th century, the population of Ljubljana numbered 5,000, 70% of whom spoke [Slovene](/wiki/Slovene_language "Slovene language") as their [first language](/wiki/First_language "First language"), with most of the rest using German.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-Histo32-54)^ The first [secondary school](/wiki/High_school_(upper_secondary) "High school (upper secondary)"), public library and printing house opened in Ljubljana. Ljubljana became an important educational centre.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-57)^{#cite_ref-57}

From 1529, Ljubljana had an active [Slovene Protestant community](/wiki/Protestant_Reformation#Slovene_Lands "Protestant Reformation"). They were expelled in 1598, marking the beginning of the [Counter-Reformation](/wiki/Counter-Reformation "Counter-Reformation"). Catholic Bishop [Thomas Chrön](/wiki/Thomas_Chr%C3%B6n "Thomas Chrön") ordered the public burning of eight cartloads of Protestant books.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-ES2-58)^^[\[58\]](#cite_note-59)^{#cite_ref-59}

In 1597, the [Jesuits](/wiki/Society_of_Jesus "Society of Jesus") arrived, followed in 1606 by the [Capuchins](/wiki/Order_of_Friars_Minor_Capuchin "Order of Friars Minor Capuchin"), seeking to [eradicate Protestantism](/wiki/Counter-Reformation "Counter-Reformation"). Only 5% of all the residents of Ljubljana at the time were Catholic, but eventually they re-Catholicized the town. The Jesuits staged the first theatre productions, fostered the development of [Baroque music](/wiki/Baroque_music "Baroque music"), and established Catholic schools. In the middle and the second half of the 17th century, foreign architects built and renovated monasteries, churches, and palaces and introduced [Baroque architecture](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture"). In 1702, the [Ursulines](/wiki/Ursulines "Ursulines") settled in the town, and the following year they opened the first public school for girls in the [Slovene Lands](/wiki/Slovene_Lands "Slovene Lands"). Some years later, the construction of the [Ursuline Church of the Holy Trinity](/wiki/Ursuline_Church_of_the_Holy_Trinity "Ursuline Church of the Holy Trinity") started.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-RKD19802-60)^^[\[60\]](#cite_note-LJinfo2-61)^ In 1779, [St. Christopher's Cemetery](/wiki/St._Christopher%27s_Cemetery "St. Christopher's Cemetery") replaced the cemetery at [St. Peter's Church](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Parish_Church_(Ljubljana) "St. Peter's Parish Church (Ljubljana)") as Ljubljana's main cemetery.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-62)^{#cite_ref-62}  

### Late modern {#Late_modern}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Late modern")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Pristani%C5%A1%C4%8De_na_Bregu_1765.jpg/220px-Pristani%C5%A1%C4%8De_na_Bregu_1765.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pristani%C5%A1%C4%8De_na_Bregu_1765.jpg) Ljubljana in the 18th century [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Leander_Russ_-_Parade_zur_Begr%C3%BC%C3%9Fung_des_Kaisers_in_Laibach_-_1845.jpeg/220px-Leander_Russ_-_Parade_zur_Begr%C3%BC%C3%9Fung_des_Kaisers_in_Laibach_-_1845.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Leander_Russ_-_Parade_zur_Begr%C3%BC%C3%9Fung_des_Kaisers_in_Laibach_-_1845.jpeg) Celebration during the [Congress of Laibach](/wiki/Congress_of_Laibach "Congress of Laibach"), 1821 [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/%C5%A0pitalski_most%2C_Marijin_trg_in_pogled_proti_%C5%A0marni_gori_z_gradu_1900.jpg/220px-%C5%A0pitalski_most%2C_Marijin_trg_in_pogled_proti_%C5%A0marni_gori_z_gradu_1900.jpg)](/wiki/File:%C5%A0pitalski_most,_Marijin_trg_in_pogled_proti_%C5%A0marni_gori_z_gradu_1900.jpg) Ljubljana, c. 1900 [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Ljubljana_in_1895_%283%29.jpg/220px-Ljubljana_in_1895_%283%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ljubljana_in_1895_(3).jpg) The 1895 earthquake destroyed much of the city centre, enabling an extensive renovation program. The oldest preserved film recordings of Ljubljana (1909), with a depiction of streets, the [Ljubljana tram](/wiki/Ljubljana_tram_system "Ljubljana tram system"), and a celebration. Salvatore Spina Company, Trieste.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-63)^^[\[63\]](#cite_note-64)^

From 1809 to 1813, during the "[Napoleonic](/wiki/Napoleon_I_of_France "Napoleon I of France") interlude", Ljubljana (as *Laybach* ) was the capital of the [Illyrian Provinces](/wiki/Illyrian_Provinces "Illyrian Provinces").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-Artis2-39)^^[\[64\]](#cite_note-Histo42-65)^ In 1813, the city returned to Austria and from 1815 to 1849 was the administrative centre of the [Kingdom of Illyria](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Illyria_(1816%E2%80%931849) "Kingdom of Illyria (1816–1849)") in the Austrian Empire.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-Cvirn20002-66)^ In 1821, it hosted the [Congress of Laibach](/wiki/Congress_of_Laibach "Congress of Laibach"), which fixed European political borders for that period.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-InfoIntro2-67)^^[\[67\]](#cite_note-68)^ The first train arrived in 1849 from Vienna and in 1857 the line extended to [Trieste](/wiki/Trieste "Trieste").^[\[64\]](#cite_note-Histo42-65)^{#cite_ref-Histo42_65-1}

In 1895, Ljubljana, then a city of 31,000, suffered [a severe earthquake](/wiki/1895_Ljubljana_earthquake "1895 Ljubljana earthquake") with a [moment magnitude](/wiki/Moment_magnitude_scale "Moment magnitude scale") of 6.1 and a maximum [EMS intensity](/wiki/European_macroseismic_scale "European macroseismic scale") of VIII--IX ("heavily damaging -- destructive").^[\[68\]](#cite_note-ARSO1-69)^ 21 people died due to the earthquake and some 10% of the city's 1,400 buildings were destroyed.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-ARSO-MPP-70)^^[\[70\]](#cite_note-ARSO12-71)^ During the subsequent reconstruction, some districts were rebuilt in the [Vienna Secession](/wiki/Vienna_Secession "Vienna Secession") style.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-Histo42-65)^ Public [electric lighting](/wiki/Incandescent_light_bulb "Incandescent light bulb") arrived in 1898. The rebuilding period between 1896 and 1910 is referred to as the "revival of Ljubljana" because of architectural changes that defined the city and for reform of urban administration, health, education and tourism. The rebuilding and quick modernisation of the city were led by the mayor [Ivan Hribar](/wiki/Ivan_Hribar "Ivan Hribar").^[\[64\]](#cite_note-Histo42-65)^{#cite_ref-Histo42_65-3}

In 1918, following the dissolution of [Austria-Hungary](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary"), the region joined the [Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-Artis2-39)^^[\[71\]](#cite_note-Histo52-72)^^[\[72\]](#cite_note-73)^ In 1929, Ljubljana became the capital of the [Drava Banovina](/wiki/Drava_Banovina "Drava Banovina"), a [Yugoslav](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia") province.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-banovina2-74)^{#cite_ref-banovina2_74-0}

In 1941, during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), [Fascist Italy](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy#Fascist_regime_(1922–1943) "Kingdom of Italy") occupied the city, and then on 3 May 1941 made *Lubiana* the capital of Italy's [Province of Ljubljana](/wiki/Province_of_Ljubljana "Province of Ljubljana")^[\[74\]](#cite_note-rodogno2-75)^ with former Yugoslav general [Leon Rupnik](/wiki/Leon_Rupnik "Leon Rupnik") as mayor. After the Italian capitulation, [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") with SS-general [Erwin Rösener](/wiki/Erwin_R%C3%B6sener "Erwin Rösener") and [Friedrich Rainer](/wiki/Friedrich_Rainer "Friedrich Rainer") took control in 1943,^[\[71\]](#cite_note-Histo52-72)^ but formally the city remained the capital of an Italian province until 9 May 1945. In Ljubljana, the Axis forces established strongholds and command centres of [Quisling](/wiki/Quisling "Quisling") organisations, the [Anti-Communist Volunteer Militia](/wiki/Anti-Communist_Volunteer_Militia "Anti-Communist Volunteer Militia") under Italy and the [Home Guard](/wiki/Slovene_Home_Guard "Slovene Home Guard") under German control. Starting in February 1942, [the city was surrounded by barbed wire](/wiki/Trail_of_Remembrance_and_Comradeship "Trail of Remembrance and Comradeship"), later fortified by [bunkers](/wiki/Bunker "Bunker"), to prevent co-operation between the [resistance movements](/wiki/Liberation_Front_of_the_Slovene_Nation "Liberation Front of the Slovene Nation") that operated inside and outside the fence.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-76)^^[\[76\]](#cite_note-60_let2-77)^ Since 1985, the [commemorative trail](/wiki/Trail_of_Remembrance_and_Comradeship "Trail of Remembrance and Comradeship") has ringed the city where this iron fence once stood.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-rideau_fer2-78)^ Postwar reprisals filled [mass graves](/wiki/Mass_graves_in_Ljubljana "Mass graves in Ljubljana").^[\[78\]](#cite_note-Booker2-79)^^[\[79\]](#cite_note-80)^^[\[80\]](#cite_note-Grahek2-81)^^[\[81\]](#cite_note-Ferenc2-82)^{#cite_ref-Ferenc2_82-0}

After World War II, Ljubljana became the capital of the [Socialist Republic of Slovenia](/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Slovenia "Socialist Republic of Slovenia"), part of the [Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia"). It retained this status until Slovene independence in 1991.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-STAT112-20)^{#cite_ref-STAT112_20-1}  

### Contemporary situation {#Contemporary_situation}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Contemporary situation")\]

Ljubljana is the capital of independent [Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia "Slovenia"), which joined the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") in 2004.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-Histo52-72)^{#cite_ref-Histo52_72-2}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Geography")\]  
[![Map](https://maps.wikimedia.org/img/osm-intl,11,46.051388888889,14.506111111111,300x200.png?lang=en&domain=en.wikipedia.org&title=Ljubljana&revid=1272773057&groups=_fca7e9c0dff4b7597778df2fd8031dd81b84549c)](/wiki/Special:Map/11/46.051388888889/14.506111111111/en)  
Map with the city, including the [motorway ring](/wiki/Ljubljana_Ring_Road "Ljubljana Ring Road")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/SmarnaGora.jpg/220px-SmarnaGora.jpg)](/wiki/File:SmarnaGora.jpg) [Mount Saint Mary](/wiki/Mount_Saint_Mary "Mount Saint Mary"), the highest hill in Ljubljana, with the peak Grmada reaching 676 m (2,218 ft)

The city covers 163.8 km^2^ (63.2 sq mi).^[\[1\]](#cite_note-SURS-1)^ It is situated in the [Ljubljana Basin](/wiki/Ljubljana_Basin "Ljubljana Basin") in [Central Slovenia](/wiki/Central_Slovenia_Statistical_Region "Central Slovenia Statistical Region"), between the [Alps](/wiki/Southern_Limestone_Alps "Southern Limestone Alps") and the [Karst](/wiki/Karst_Plateau "Karst Plateau"). Ljubljana is located some 320 km (200 mi) south of [Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich"), 477 km (296 mi) east of [Zürich](/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich "Zürich"), 250 km (160 mi) east of Venice, 350 km (220 mi) southwest of [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), 124 km (77 mi) west of [Zagreb](/wiki/Zagreb "Zagreb") and 400 km (250 mi) southwest of [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest").^[\[82\]](#cite_note-83)^ Ljubljana has grown considerably since the 1970s, mainly by merging with nearby settlements.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-84)^{#cite_ref-84}  

### Geology {#Geology}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Geology")\]

The city stretches out on an [alluvial](/wiki/Alluvium "Alluvium") plain dating to the [Quaternary](/wiki/Quaternary "Quaternary") [era](/wiki/Geologic_time_scale "Geologic time scale"). The mountainous regions nearby are older, dating from the [Mesozoic](/wiki/Mesozoic "Mesozoic") ([Triassic](/wiki/Triassic "Triassic")) or [Paleozoic](/wiki/Paleozoic "Paleozoic").^[\[84\]](#cite_note-Geologymap2-85)^ Earthquakes have repeatedly devastated Ljubljana, notably in [1511](/wiki/1511_Idrija_earthquake "1511 Idrija earthquake") and [1895](/wiki/1895_Ljubljana_earthquake "1895 Ljubljana earthquake").^[\[85\]](#cite_note-Adamič19952-86)^{#cite_ref-Adamič19952_86-0}  

### Topography {#Topography}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Topography")\]

Ljubljana has an elevation of 295 m (968 ft).^[\[86\]](#cite_note-YB20022-87)^ The [city centre](/wiki/City_centre "City centre"), located along the river, sits at 298 m (978 ft).^[\[87\]](#cite_note-Mesto20062-88)^ [Ljubljana Castle](/wiki/Ljubljana_Castle "Ljubljana Castle"), which sits atop Castle Hill (*Grajski grič*) south of the city centre, has an elevation of 366 m (1,201 ft). The highest point of the city, called [Grmada](/wiki/Grmada_(Ljubljana) "Grmada (Ljubljana)"), reaches 676 m (2,218 ft), 3 m (9.8 ft) more than the nearby [Mount Saint Mary](/wiki/Mount_Saint_Mary "Mount Saint Mary") (*Šmarna gora*) peak, a popular hiking destination.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-Geopedia2012-01-302-89)^^[\[89\]](#cite_note-90)^ These are located in the northern part of the city.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-Geopedia2012-01-302-89)^{#cite_ref-Geopedia2012-01-302_89-1}

The building density there is substantially lower due to unsuitable ground for construction.")

### Bodies of water {#Bodies_of_water}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Bodies of water")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Ljubljana_old_town_with_excursion_boat.JPG/220px-Ljubljana_old_town_with_excursion_boat.JPG)](/wiki/File:Ljubljana_old_town_with_excursion_boat.JPG) The Ljubljanica in the centre of the city [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Ljubljanica_banks_night.jpg/220px-Ljubljanica_banks_night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ljubljanica_banks_night.jpg) Bridges across the Ljubljanica River are popular tourist attractions [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Kose%C5%A1ki_bajer.jpg/220px-Kose%C5%A1ki_bajer.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kose%C5%A1ki_bajer.jpg) Koseze Pond is used for rowing, fishing, and ice skating in winter.

The main watercourses in Ljubljana are the [Ljubljanica](/wiki/Ljubljanica "Ljubljanica"), the [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava"), the [Gradaščica](/wiki/Grada%C5%A1%C4%8Dica "Gradaščica"), the [Mali Graben](/wiki/Mali_Graben "Mali Graben"), the [Iška](/wiki/I%C5%A1ka "Iška") and the Iščica rivers. From the [Trnovo District](/wiki/Trnovo_District "Trnovo District") to the [Moste District](/wiki/Moste_District "Moste District"), around Castle Hill, the Ljubljanica partly flows through the [Gruber Canal](/w/index.php?title=Gruber_Canal&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gruber Canal (page does not exist)"), built according to plans by [Gabriel Gruber](/wiki/Gabriel_Gruber "Gabriel Gruber") from 1772 until 1780. Next to the eastern border, the rivers Ljubljanica, Sava, and [Kamnik Bistrica](/wiki/Kamnik_Bistrica "Kamnik Bistrica") flow together.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-91)^^[\[91\]](#cite_note-92)^ The confluence is the lowest point of Ljubljana, with an elevation of 261 m (856 ft).^[\[87\]](#cite_note-Mesto20062-88)^{#cite_ref-Mesto20062_88-1}

Through its history, Ljubljana has been struck by floods. [The latest](/wiki/2023_Slovenia_floods "2023 Slovenia floods") was in August 2023, when the [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") and Gradaščica rivers flooded in their upper reaches.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-93)^ Southern and western parts of the city are more flood-endangered than northern parts.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-Ocena_poplave2-94)^ The Gruber Canal has partly diminished the danger of floods in the [Ljubljana Marsh](/wiki/Ljubljana_Marsh "Ljubljana Marsh"), the largest marsh in Slovenia, south of the city.{#cite_ref-Ocena_poplave2_94-0}

The two major ponds in Ljubljana are [Koseze Pond](/wiki/Koseze_Pond "Koseze Pond") in the Šiška District and [Tivoli Pond](/wiki/Tivoli_Pond "Tivoli Pond") in the southern part of [Tivoli City Park](/wiki/Tivoli_City_Park "Tivoli City Park").^[\[94\]](#cite_note-95)^ Koseze Pond has rare plant and animal species and is a place of meeting and recreation.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-96)^ Tivoli Pond is a shallow pond with a small volume that was originally used for boating and ice skating, but is now used for fishing.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-Krelj20122-97)^{#cite_ref-Krelj20122_97-0}  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Ljubljana's climate is [oceanic](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): Cfb), bordering on a [humid subtropical climate](/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid subtropical climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): Cfa), with [continental](/wiki/Continental_climate "Continental climate") characteristics such as warm summers and moderately cold winters.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-98)^^[\[98\]](#cite_note-99)^ July and August are the warmest months with daily high temperatures generally between 25 and 30 °C (77 and 86 °F), and January is the coldest month with temperatures mostly around 0 °C (32 °F). The city experiences up to 90 days of frost per year, and 11 days with temperatures above 30 °C (86 °F) (often even more). Precipitation is relatively evenly distributed throughout the seasons, although winter and spring tend to be somewhat drier than summer and autumn. Yearly precipitation is about 1,400 mm (55 in), making Ljubljana one of the wettest European capitals. Thunderstorms are common from May to September and can occasionally be heavy. Snow is common from December to February; on average, snow cover is recorded for 48 days a year. The city is known for its fog, appearing on average on 64 days per year, mostly in autumn and winter, and can be particularly persistent in conditions of [temperature inversion](/wiki/Inversion_(meteorology) "Inversion (meteorology)").^[\[99\]](#cite_note-ARSO2-100)^{#cite_ref-ARSO2_100-0}

Cityscape {#Cityscape}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/View_on_Ljubljana_from_Neboti%C4%8Dnik_Tower_%2838458386985%29.jpg/900px-View_on_Ljubljana_from_Neboti%C4%8Dnik_Tower_%2838458386985%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:View_on_Ljubljana_from_Neboti%C4%8Dnik_Tower_(38458386985).jpg "View of Ljubljana from Nebotičnik; Ljubljana Castle is on the left.")  
[](/wiki/File:View_on_Ljubljana_from_Neboti%C4%8Dnik_Tower_(38458386985).jpg "File:View on Ljubljana from Nebotičnik Tower (38458386985).jpg") View of Ljubljana from Nebotičnik; Ljubljana Castle is on the left.

The city's architecture is a mix of styles. Large buildings have appeared around the city's edges, while Ljubljana's historic centre remains intact. Some of the oldest architecture dates to the Roman period, while Ljubljana's downtown got its outline in the Middle Ages.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-109)^ After the [1511 earthquake](/wiki/1511_Western_Slovenia_earthquake "1511 Western Slovenia earthquake"), it was rebuilt in the [Baroque style](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") following Italian, particularly Venetian, models.{#cite_ref-109}

After the earthquake in 1895, it was again rebuilt, this time in the [Vienna Secession](/wiki/Vienna_Secession "Vienna Secession") style, which is juxtaposed against the earlier Baroque style buildings that remain. Large sectors built in the inter-war period often include a personal touch by the architects [Jože Plečnik](/wiki/Jo%C5%BEe_Ple%C4%8Dnik "Jože Plečnik")^[\[109\]](#cite_note-RTV2006-05-312-110)^ and [Ivan Vurnik](/wiki/Ivan_Vurnik "Ivan Vurnik").^[\[110\]](#cite_note-111)^ In the second half of the 20th century, parts of Ljubljana were redesigned by [Edvard Ravnikar](/wiki/Edvard_Ravnikar "Edvard Ravnikar").^[\[111\]](#cite_note-112)^{#cite_ref-112}  

### Central {#Central}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Central")\]

The central square in Ljubljana is [Prešeren Square](/wiki/Pre%C5%A1eren_Square "Prešeren Square") (*Prešernov trg*) home to the [Franciscan Church of the Annunciation](/wiki/Franciscan_Church_of_the_Annunciation "Franciscan Church of the Annunciation") (*Frančiškanska cerkev*). Built between 1646 and 1660 (the bell towers followed), it replaced an older Gothic church. It offers an early-Baroque basilica with one nave and two rows of lateral chapels. The Baroque main altar was executed by sculptor Italian [Francesco Robba](/wiki/Francesco_Robba "Francesco Robba"). Much of the original frescos were ruined by ceiling cracks caused by the [Ljubljana earthquake in 1895](/wiki/1895_Ljubljana_earthquake "1895 Ljubljana earthquake"). The new frescos were painted by the Slovene [impressionist](/wiki/Impressionist "Impressionist") painter [Matej Sternen](/wiki/Matej_Sternen "Matej Sternen").

[Ljubljana Castle](/wiki/Ljubljana_Castle "Ljubljana Castle") (*Ljubljanski grad* ) is a medieval castle with [Romanesque](/wiki/Romanesque_architecture "Romanesque architecture"), [Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture"), and [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture") architectural elements, located on the summit of Castle Hill, which dominates the city centre.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-113)^ The area surrounding the castle has been continuously inhabited since 1200 BC.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-LubljanaCastle2-114)^ The castle was built in the 12th century and was a residence of the [Margraves](/wiki/Margrave "Margrave"), later the [Dukes of Carniola](/wiki/Duchy_of_Carniola "Duchy of Carniola").^[\[114\]](#cite_note-115)^ Its Viewing Tower dates to 1848; it was manned by a guard whose duty it was to fire cannons announcing fire or important visitors or events, a function the castle still holds.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-LubljanaCastle2-114)^ Cultural events and weddings also take place there.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-LubljanaFestival2-116)^ In 2006, a [funicular](/wiki/Ljubljana_Castle_funicular "Ljubljana Castle funicular") linked the city centre to the castle.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/StNicholas-Ljubljana.JPG/220px-StNicholas-Ljubljana.JPG)](/wiki/File:StNicholas-Ljubljana.JPG) Ljubljana Cathedral

[Town Hall](/wiki/Ljubljana_Town_Hall "Ljubljana Town Hall") (*Mestna hiša*, *Magistrat*), located at [Town Square](/wiki/Town_Square_(Ljubljana) "Town Square (Ljubljana)"), is the seat of [city government](/wiki/City_Municipality_of_Ljubljana "City Municipality of Ljubljana"). The original, Gothic building was completed in 1484.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-118)^ Between 1717 and 1719,^[\[109\]](#cite_note-RTV2006-05-312-110)^ the building underwent a Baroque renovation with a Venetian inspiration by architect Gregor Maček Sr.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-119)^ Near Town Hall, at [Town Square](/wiki/Town_Square_(Ljubljana) "Town Square (Ljubljana)"), stands a replica of the Baroque [Robba Fountain](/wiki/Robba_Fountain "Robba Fountain"). The original was moved into the [National Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Slovenia "National Gallery of Slovenia") in 2006. The fountain is decorated with an obelisk; at the foot are three figures in white marble symbolising the three chief rivers of Carniola. It is work of Francesco Robba, who designed other Baroque statues there.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-Baroque2-120)^{#cite_ref-Baroque2_120-0}

[Ljubljana Cathedral](/wiki/Ljubljana_Cathedral "Ljubljana Cathedral") (*ljubljanska stolnica*), or St. Nicholas's Cathedral (*stolnica sv. Nikolaja*), serves the [Archdiocese of Ljubljana](/wiki/Archdiocese_of_Ljubljana "Archdiocese of Ljubljana"). Easily identifiable due to its green dome and twin towers, it is located at Cyril and Methodius Square (*Ciril-Metodov trg*, named for [Saints Cyril and Methodius](/wiki/Saints_Cyril_and_Methodius "Saints Cyril and Methodius")).^[\[120\]](#cite_note-LubljanaCathedrale2-121)^ The Diocese was set up in 1461.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-LubljanaCathedrale2-121)^ Between 1701 and 1706, Jesuit architect [Andrea Pozzo](/wiki/Andrea_Pozzo "Andrea Pozzo") designed the Baroque church with two side chapels shaped in the form of a [Latin cross](/wiki/Christian_cross "Christian cross").^[\[120\]](#cite_note-LubljanaCathedrale2-121)^ The dome was built in the centre in 1841.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-LubljanaCathedrale2-121)^ The interior is decorated with Baroque frescos painted by [Giulio Quaglio](/wiki/Giulio_Quaglio_the_Younger "Giulio Quaglio the Younger") between 1703--1706 and 1721--1723.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-LubljanaCathedrale2-121)^{#cite_ref-LubljanaCathedrale2_121-4}

[Nebotičnik](/wiki/Neboti%C4%8Dnik "Nebotičnik") (pronounced [\[nɛbɔtiːtʃniːk\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Slovene "Help:IPA/Slovene"), "Skyscraper") is a thirteen-story building that rises to a height of 70.35 m (231 ft). It combines elements of [Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") and [Art-Deco](/wiki/Art-Deco "Art-Deco") architecture. Predominantly a place of business, Nebotičnik is home to shops on the ground floor and first story, and offices are located on floors two to five. The sixth to ninth floors are private residences. The top three floors host a café, bar and observation deck.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-Ljubljana.si2-122)^ It was designed by Slovenian architect [Vladimir Šubic](/wiki/Vladimir_%C5%A0ubic "Vladimir Šubic"). The building opened on 21 February 1933.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-govcomm2-123)^ It was once the tallest residential building in Europe.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-govcomm2-123)^{#cite_ref-govcomm2_123-1}
