Public green spaces {#Public_green_spaces}
------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Public green spaces")\]

[Tivoli City Park](/wiki/Tivoli_City_Park "Tivoli City Park") (*Mestni park Tivoli*) is the largest park.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-CulturalHeritage2-124)^^[\[124\]](#cite_note-LjubljanaLife2-125)^ It was designed in 1813 by French engineer Jean Blanchard and now covers approximately 5 km^2^ (1.9 sq mi).^[\[123\]](#cite_note-CulturalHeritage2-124)^ The park was laid out during the [French imperial](/wiki/French_First_Empire "French First Empire") administration of Ljubljana in 1813 and named after the [Parisian](/wiki/Paris "Paris") [Jardins de Tivoli](/wiki/Jardin_de_Tivoli,_Paris "Jardin de Tivoli, Paris").^[\[123\]](#cite_note-CulturalHeritage2-124)^ Between 1921 and 1939, it was renovated by [Slovene](/wiki/Slovenes "Slovenes") architect [Jože Plečnik](/wiki/Jo%C5%BEe_Ple%C4%8Dnik "Jože Plečnik"), who unveiled his statue of Napoleon in 1929 in Republic Square and designed a broad central promenade, called the [Jakopič Promenade](/w/index.php?title=Jakopi%C4%8D_Promenade&action=edit&redlink=1 "Jakopič Promenade (page does not exist)") (*Jakopičevo sprehajališče*) after the leading Slovene [impressionist](/wiki/Impressionism "Impressionism") painter [Rihard Jakopič](/wiki/Rihard_Jakopi%C4%8D "Rihard Jakopič").^[\[123\]](#cite_note-CulturalHeritage2-124)^^[\[124\]](#cite_note-LjubljanaLife2-125)^ Within the park, there are trees, flower gardens, several statues, and fountains.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-CulturalHeritage2-124)^^[\[124\]](#cite_note-LjubljanaLife2-125)^ Several notable buildings stand in the park, among them [Tivoli Castle](/wiki/Tivoli_Castle "Tivoli Castle"), the [National Museum of Contemporary History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Contemporary_History "National Museum of Contemporary History") and the [Tivoli Sports Hall](/wiki/Tivoli_Hall "Tivoli Hall").^[\[123\]](#cite_note-CulturalHeritage2-124)^{#cite_ref-CulturalHeritage2_124-5}

[Tivoli--Rožnik Hill--Šiška Hill Landscape Park](/w/index.php?title=Tivoli%E2%80%93Ro%C5%BEnik_Hill%E2%80%93%C5%A0i%C5%A1ka_Hill_Landscape_Park&action=edit&redlink=1 "Tivoli–Rožnik Hill–Šiška Hill Landscape Park (page does not exist)") is located in the western part of the city.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-Lešnik20032-126)^{#cite_ref-Lešnik20032_126-0}

The [Ljubljana Botanical Garden](/wiki/Ljubljana_Botanical_Garden "Ljubljana Botanical Garden") (*Ljubljanski botanični vrt*) covers 2.40 ha (5.9 acres) next to the junction of the [Gruber Canal](/w/index.php?title=Gruber_Canal&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gruber Canal (page does not exist)") and the Ljubljanica, south of the Old Town. It is the central Slovenian [botanical garden](/wiki/Botanical_garden "Botanical garden") and the oldest cultural, scientific, and educational organisation in the country. It started operating under the leadership of [Franc Hladnik](/wiki/Franc_Hladnik "Franc Hladnik") in 1810. Of over 4,500 plant [species](/wiki/Species "Species") and [subspecies](/wiki/Subspecies "Subspecies"), roughly a third is [endemic](/wiki/Endemism "Endemism") to Slovenia, whereas the rest originate from other European places and other continents. The institution is a member of the international network [Botanic Gardens Conservation International](/wiki/Botanic_Gardens_Conservation_International "Botanic Gardens Conservation International") and cooperates with more than 270 botanical gardens all across the world.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-127)^{#cite_ref-127}

In 2014, Ljubljana won the [European Green Capital Award](/wiki/European_Green_Capital_Award "European Green Capital Award") for 2016 for their environmental achievements.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-128)^{#cite_ref-128}  

### Bridges, streets and squares {#Bridges.2C_streets_and_squares}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Bridges, streets and squares")\]

Ljubljana's best-known bridges, listed from northern to southern ones, include the [Dragon Bridge](/wiki/Dragon_Bridge_(Ljubljana) "Dragon Bridge (Ljubljana)") (*Zmajski most*), the [Butchers' Bridge](/wiki/Butchers%27_Bridge "Butchers' Bridge") (*Mesarski most*), the [Triple Bridge](/wiki/Triple_Bridge "Triple Bridge") (*Tromostovje*), the [Fish Footbridge](/w/index.php?title=Fish_Footbridge&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fish Footbridge (page does not exist)") ([Slovene](/wiki/Slovene_language "Slovene language"): *Ribja brv* ), the [Cobblers' Bridge](/wiki/Cobblers%27_Bridge "Cobblers' Bridge") ([Slovene](/wiki/Slovene_language "Slovene language"): *Šuštarski most* ), the [Hradecky Bridge](/wiki/Hradecky_Bridge "Hradecky Bridge") ([Slovene](/wiki/Slovene_language "Slovene language"): *Hradeckega most* ), and the [Trnovo Bridge](/wiki/Trnovo_Bridge "Trnovo Bridge") (*Trnovski most*). The last mentioned crosses the [Gradaščica](/wiki/Grada%C5%A1%C4%8Dica "Gradaščica"), whereas all other bridges cross the [Ljubljanica River](/wiki/Ljubljanica_River "Ljubljanica River").  

#### The Dragon Bridge {#The_Dragon_Bridge}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: The Dragon Bridge")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Dragon_Bridge_1_%285756113569%29.jpg/220px-Dragon_Bridge_1_%285756113569%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dragon_Bridge_1_(5756113569).jpg) Dragon statue on the [Dragon Bridge](/wiki/Dragon_Bridge_(Ljubljana) "Dragon Bridge (Ljubljana)")

The 1901 [Dragon Bridge](/wiki/Dragon_Bridge_(Ljubljana) "Dragon Bridge (Ljubljana)"), decorated with dragon statues^[\[128\]](#cite_note-129)^ on pedestals at four corners of the bridge^[\[129\]](#cite_note-ECCENET2-130)^^[\[130\]](#cite_note-SBTG842-131)^ has become a symbol of the city^[\[131\]](#cite_note-LJUBLJANA2-132)^ and is regarded as one of the most beautiful examples of a bridge made in [Vienna Secession](/wiki/Vienna_Secession "Vienna Secession") style.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-ARCH1242-27)^^[\[132\]](#cite_note-S652-133)^^[\[131\]](#cite_note-LJUBLJANA2-132)^^[\[133\]](#cite_note-IABC2-134)^ It has a span of 33.34 m (109 ft 5 in)^[\[26\]](#cite_note-ARCH1242-27)^ and its arch was at the time the third largest in Europe.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-ECCENET2-130)^ It is protected as a technical monument.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-ARCH124b2-135)^{#cite_ref-ARCH124b2_135-0}  

#### The Butchers' Bridge {#The_Butchers.27_Bridge}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: The Butchers' Bridge")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Love_padlocks_on_the_Butchers%27_Bridge_%28Ljubljana%29.jpg/220px-Love_padlocks_on_the_Butchers%27_Bridge_%28Ljubljana%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Love_padlocks_on_the_Butchers%27_Bridge_(Ljubljana).jpg) Butchers' Bridge [love locks](/wiki/Love_lock "Love lock")

Decorated with mythological bronze sculptures, created by [Jakov Brdar](/wiki/Jakov_Brdar "Jakov Brdar"), from Ancient Greek mythology and Biblical stories,^[\[135\]](#cite_note-136)^ the Butchers' Bridge connects the [Ljubljana Open Market](/wiki/Ljubljana_Central_Market "Ljubljana Central Market") area and the restaurants-filled [Petkovšek Embankment](/w/index.php?title=Petkov%C5%A1ek_Embankment&action=edit&redlink=1 "Petkovšek Embankment (page does not exist)") (*Petkovškovo nabrežje*). It is also known as the [love padlocks](/wiki/Love_padlocks "Love padlocks")-decorated bridge in Ljubljana.{#cite_ref-136}  

#### The Triple Bridge {#The_Triple_Bridge}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: The Triple Bridge")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/bb/Ljubljana_in_Ljubljanica.jpg/220px-Ljubljana_in_Ljubljanica.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ljubljana_in_Ljubljanica.jpg) The scenic Triple Bridge, decorated with stone balusters and stone lamps on all of the three bridges

The [Triple Bridge](/wiki/Triple_Bridge "Triple Bridge") is decorated with stone [balusters](/wiki/Baluster "Baluster") and stone lamps on all of the three bridges and leads to the terraces looking on the river and poplar trees. It occupies a central point on the east--west axis, connecting the [Tivoli City Park](/wiki/Tivoli_City_Park "Tivoli City Park") with [Rožnik Hill](/wiki/Ro%C5%BEnik_Hill "Rožnik Hill"), on one side, and the [Ljubljana Castle](/wiki/Ljubljana_Castle "Ljubljana Castle") on the other,^[\[136\]](#cite_note-137)^ and the north--south axis through the city, represented by the river. It was enlarged in order to prevent the historically single bridge from being a [bottleneck](/wiki/Bottleneck_(traffic) "Bottleneck (traffic)") by adding two side [pedestrian](/wiki/Pedestrian "Pedestrian") bridges to the middle one.{#cite_ref-137}  

#### The Fish Footbridge {#The_Fish_Footbridge}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: The Fish Footbridge")\]

The Fish Footbridge offers a view of the neighbouring Triple Bridge to the north and the Cobbler's Bridge to the South. It is a transparent glass-made bridge, illuminated at night by in-built LEDs.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-138)^ From 1991 to 2014 the bridge was a wooden one and decorated with flowers, while since its reconstruction in 2014, it is made of glass. It was planned already in 1895 by [Max Fabiani](/wiki/Max_Fabiani "Max Fabiani") to build a bridge on the location, in 1913 [Alfred Keller](/wiki/Alfred_Keller "Alfred Keller") planned a staircase, later [Jože Plečnik](/wiki/Jo%C5%BEe_Ple%C4%8Dnik "Jože Plečnik") incorporated both into his own plans which, however, were not realised.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-139)^{#cite_ref-139}  

#### The Cobbler's Bridge {#The_Cobbler.27s_Bridge}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: The Cobbler's Bridge")\]

The 1930 'Cobblers' Bridge' (*Šuštarski*, from German *Schuster* -- Shoemaker) is another [Plečnik](/wiki/Ple%C4%8Dnik "Plečnik")'s creation, connecting two major areas of medieval Ljubljana. It is decorated by two kinds of pillars, the [Corinthian pillars](/wiki/Corinthian_pillar "Corinthian pillar") which delineate the shape of the bridge itself and the [Ionic pillars](/wiki/Ionic_order "Ionic order") as lamp-bearers.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-140)^{#cite_ref-140}  

#### The Trnovo Bridge {#The_Trnovo_Bridge}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: The Trnovo Bridge")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Trnovo_Bridge.jpg/220px-Trnovo_Bridge.jpg)](/wiki/File:Trnovo_Bridge.jpg) Trnovo Bridge

The Trnovo Bridge is the most prominent object of Plečnik's renovation of the banks of the Gradaščica. It is located in the front of the [Trnovo Church](/w/index.php?title=Trnovo_Church&action=edit&redlink=1 "Trnovo Church (page does not exist)") to the south of the city centre. It connects the neighbourhoods of [Krakovo](/w/index.php?title=Krakovo&action=edit&redlink=1 "Krakovo (page does not exist)") and [Trnovo](/wiki/Trnovo,_Ljubljana "Trnovo, Ljubljana"), the oldest Ljubljana suburbs, known for their market gardens and cultural events.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-141)^ It was built between 1929 and 1932. It is distinguished by its width and two rows of [birches](/wiki/Birch "Birch") that it bears, because it was meant to serve as a public space in front of the church. Each corner of the bridge is capped with a small pyramid, a signature motif of Plečnik's, whereas the mid-span features a pair of [Art-Deco](/wiki/Art-Deco "Art-Deco") male sculptures. There is also a statue of [Saint John the Baptist](/wiki/John_the_Baptist "John the Baptist") on the bridge, the patron of the Trnovo Church. It was designed by [Nikolaj Pirnat](/wiki/Nikolaj_Pirnat "Nikolaj Pirnat").{#cite_ref-141}  

#### The Hradecky Bridge {#The_Hradecky_Bridge}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: The Hradecky Bridge")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Hradecky_Bridge.jpg/220px-Hradecky_Bridge.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hradecky_Bridge.jpg) Hradecky Bridge \[hinged bridge\]

The [Hradecky Bridge](/wiki/Hradecky_Bridge "Hradecky Bridge") is one of the first [hinged bridges](/w/index.php?title=Hinged_bridge&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hinged bridge (page does not exist)") in the world,^[\[141\]](#cite_note-ARCH1262-142)^ the first^[\[142\]](#cite_note-Slivnik20102-143)^ and the only preserved [cast iron](/wiki/Cast_iron "Cast iron") bridge in Slovenia,^[\[143\]](#cite_note-144)^ and one of its most highly valued technical achievements.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-LJ2011-05-122-145)^^[\[145\]](#cite_note-Trbižan20112-146)^ It has been situated on an extension of [Hren Street](/w/index.php?title=Hren_Street_(Ljubljana)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hren Street (Ljubljana) (page does not exist)") (*Hrenova ulica*), between the [Krakovo Embankment](/w/index.php?title=Krakovo_Embankment&action=edit&redlink=1 "Krakovo Embankment (page does not exist)") (*Krakovski nasip*) and the [Gruden Embankment](/w/index.php?title=Gruden_Embankment&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gruden Embankment (page does not exist)") (*Grudnovo nabrežje*), connecting the [Trnovo District](/wiki/Trnovo_District "Trnovo District") and the [Prule](/w/index.php?title=Prule&action=edit&redlink=1 "Prule (page does not exist)") neighbourhood in the [Center District](/wiki/Center_District,_Ljubljana "Center District, Ljubljana").^[\[146\]](#cite_note-RKD3652-147)^ The Hradecky Bridge was manufactured according to the plans of the senior engineer [Johann Hermann](/w/index.php?title=Johann_Hermann_(engineer)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Johann Hermann (engineer) (page does not exist)") from Vienna in the [Auersperg iron foundry](/w/index.php?title=Auersperg_iron_foundry,_Dvor&action=edit&redlink=1 "Auersperg iron foundry, Dvor (page does not exist)") in [Dvor near Žužemberk](/wiki/Dvor,_%C5%BDu%C5%BEemberk "Dvor, Žužemberk"),^[\[145\]](#cite_note-Trbižan20112-146)^ and installed in Ljubljana in 1867, at the location of today's [Cobblers' Bridge](/wiki/Cobblers%27_Bridge "Cobblers' Bridge").^[\[147\]](#cite_note-Geopedia.si2-148)^{#cite_ref-Geopedia.si2_148-0}  

#### Streets and squares {#Streets_and_squares}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Streets and squares")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Ljubljana_streets_%2811330213013%29.jpg/220px-Ljubljana_streets_%2811330213013%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ljubljana_streets_(11330213013).jpg) Čop Street [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Ljubljana_stritarjeva_ulica.jpg/220px-Ljubljana_stritarjeva_ulica.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ljubljana_stritarjeva_ulica.jpg) Stritar Street with the Robba Fountain

Having already existed in the 18th century, Ljubljana's central square, [Prešeren Square](/wiki/Pre%C5%A1eren_Square_(Ljubljana) "Prešeren Square (Ljubljana)")'s modern appearance has developed since the end of the 19th century. After the 1895 earthquake, [Max Fabiani](/wiki/Max_Fabiani "Max Fabiani") designed the square as the hub of four streets and four banks, and in the 1980s [Edvard Ravnikar](/wiki/Edvard_Ravnikar "Edvard Ravnikar") proposed the circular design and the granite block pavement.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-149)^^[\[149\]](#cite_note-150)^ A statue of the Slovene [national poet](/wiki/List_of_national_poets "List of national poets") [France Prešeren](/wiki/France_Pre%C5%A1eren "France Prešeren") with a [muse](/wiki/Muse "Muse") stands in the middle of the square. The [Prešeren Monument](/wiki/Pre%C5%A1eren_Monument_(Ljubljana) "Prešeren Monument (Ljubljana)") was created by [Ivan Zajec](/wiki/Ivan_Zajec "Ivan Zajec") in 1905, whereas the pedestal was designed by Max Fabiani. The square and surroundings have been closed to traffic since 1 September 2007.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-caf2-151)^ Only a tourist train leaves Prešeren Square every day, transporting tourists to [Ljubljana Castle](/wiki/Ljubljana_Castle "Ljubljana Castle").^[\[150\]](#cite_note-caf2-151)^{#cite_ref-caf2_151-1}

[Republic Square](/wiki/Republic_Square_(Ljubljana) "Republic Square (Ljubljana)"), originally named Revolution Square, is the largest square in Ljubljana.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-DEDITR3-152)^ It was designed in the second half of the 20th century by Edvard Ravnikar.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-DEDITR3-152)^ On 26 June 1991, the independence of Slovenia was declared here.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-DEDITR3-152)^ The [National Assembly Building](/wiki/National_Assembly_Building_of_Slovenia "National Assembly Building of Slovenia") stands at its northern side, and [Cankar Hall](/wiki/Cankar_Hall "Cankar Hall"), the largest Slovenian cultural and congress centre, at the southern side.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-DEDITR3-152)^ At its eastern side stands the two-storey building of [Maximarket](/w/index.php?title=Maximarket&action=edit&redlink=1 "Maximarket (page does not exist)"), also the work of Ravnikar. It houses one of the oldest department stores in Ljubljana and a cafe, which is a popular meeting place and a place for political talks and negotiations.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-DEDITR22-153)^{#cite_ref-DEDITR22_153-0}

[Congress Square](/wiki/Congress_Square "Congress Square") (*Kongresni trg*) is one of the important centres of the city. It was built in 1821 for ceremonial purposes such as [Congress of Ljubljana](/wiki/Congress_of_Laibach "Congress of Laibach") after which it was named. Since then it has been a centre for political ceremonies, demonstrations, and protests, such as the ceremony for the creation of the [Kingdom of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia"), ceremony of the liberation of [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade"), and protests against [Yugoslav authority](/wiki/JBTZ_trial "JBTZ trial") in 1988. The square also houses several important buildings, such as the [University of Ljubljana Palace](/wiki/University_of_Ljubljana "University of Ljubljana"), [Philharmonic Hall](/wiki/Slovenian_Philharmonic "Slovenian Philharmonic"), [Ursuline Church of the Holy Trinity](/wiki/Ursuline_Church_of_the_Holy_Trinity "Ursuline Church of the Holy Trinity"), and the [Slovene Society Building](/wiki/Slovene_Society "Slovene Society"). Star Park (*Park Zvezda*) is located in the centre of the square. In 2010 and 2011, the square was renovated and is now mostly closed to road traffic on ground area, however, there are five floors for commercial purposes and a parking lot located underground.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}

[Čop Street](/wiki/%C4%8Cop_Street "Čop Street") (*Čopova ulica*) is a major thoroughfare in the centre of Ljubljana. The street is named after [Matija Čop](/wiki/Matija_%C4%8Cop "Matija Čop"), an early 19th-century literary figure and close friend of the Slovene [Romantic poet](/wiki/Romantic_poetry "Romantic poetry") [France Prešeren](/wiki/France_Pre%C5%A1eren "France Prešeren"). It leads from the [Main Post Office](/w/index.php?title=Main_Post_Office_Palace_(Ljubljana)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Main Post Office Palace (Ljubljana) (page does not exist)") (*Glavna pošta*) at [Slovene Street](/w/index.php?title=Slovene_Street_(Ljubljana)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Slovene Street (Ljubljana) (page does not exist)") (*Slovenska cesta*) downward to Prešeren Square and is lined with bars and stores, including the oldest [McDonald's restaurant](/wiki/McDonald%27s "McDonald's") in Slovenia. It is a pedestrian zone and regarded as the capital's central [promenade](/wiki/Promenade "Promenade").  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Culture")\]  

### Accent {#Accent}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Accent")\]

The Ljubljana accent and/or dialect ([Slovene](/wiki/Slovene_language "Slovene language"): *ljubljanščina* [\[luːblɑːŋʃnɑː\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Slovene "Help:IPA/Slovene") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/f/fb/Lublansna.ogg/Lublansna.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Lublansna.ogg "File:Lublansna.ogg")^) is considered a border dialect, since Ljubljana is situated where the [Upper](/wiki/Upper_Carniolan_dialect_group "Upper Carniolan dialect group") dialect and [Lower Carniolan dialect group](/wiki/Lower_Carniolan_dialect_group "Lower Carniolan dialect group") meet. Historically,^[\[154\]](#cite_note-Osnove_Trubarjevega_jezika2-155)^ the Ljubljana dialect in the past displayed features more similar with the Lower Carniolan dialect group, but it gradually grew closer to the Upper dialect group, as a direct consequence of mass migration from Upper Carniola into Ljubljana in the 19th and 20th century. Ljubljana as a city grew mostly to the north, and gradually incorporated many villages that were historically part of [Upper Carniola](/wiki/Upper_Carniola "Upper Carniola") and so its dialect shifted away and closer to the [Upper](/wiki/Upper_Carniolan_dialect_group "Upper Carniolan dialect group") dialects. The Ljubljana dialect has also been used as a literary means in novels, such as in the novel *Nekdo drug* by [Branko Gradišnik](/wiki/Branko_Gradi%C5%A1nik "Branko Gradišnik"),^[\[155\]](#cite_note-Gjurin_Gradisnik2-156)^ or in poems, such as *Pika Nogavička* (Slovene for [Pippi Longstocking](/wiki/Pippi_Longstocking "Pippi Longstocking")) by [Andrej Rozman - Roza](/wiki/Andrej_Rozman_-_Roza "Andrej Rozman - Roza").^[\[156\]](#cite_note-Blažič_Rozman2-157)^{#cite_ref-Blažič_Rozman2_157-0}

The central position of Ljubljana and its dialect had crucial impact^[\[154\]](#cite_note-Osnove_Trubarjevega_jezika2-155)^ on the development of the Slovenian language. It was the speech of 16th century Ljubljana that [Primož Trubar](/wiki/Primo%C5%BE_Trubar "Primož Trubar") a Slovenian [Protestant Reformer](/wiki/Protestant_Reformers "Protestant Reformers") took as a foundation of what later became standard [Slovenian language](/wiki/Slovenian_language "Slovenian language"), with a small addition of his native speech, the [Lower Carniolan dialect](/wiki/Lower_Carniolan_dialect "Lower Carniolan dialect").^[\[154\]](#cite_note-Osnove_Trubarjevega_jezika2-155)^^[\[157\]](#cite_note-158)^ While in Ljubljana, he lived in a house, on today's Ribji trg, in the oldest part of the city. Living in Ljubljana had a profound impact on his work; he considered Ljubljana the capital of all [Slovenes](/wiki/Slovenes "Slovenes"), not only because of its central position in the heart of the [Slovene lands](/wiki/Slovene_lands "Slovene lands"), but also because it always had an essentially Slovene character. Most of its inhabitants spoke Slovene as their mother tongue, unlike other cites in today's [Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia "Slovenia"). It is estimated that in Trubar's time around 70% of Ljubljana's 4000 inhabitants attended mass in Slovene.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-Osnove_Trubarjevega_jezika2-155)^ Trubar considered Ljubljana's speech most suitable, since it sounded much more noble than his own simple dialect of his hometown [Rašica](/wiki/Ra%C5%A1ica,_Velike_La%C5%A1%C4%8De "Rašica, Velike Lašče").^[\[158\]](#cite_note-159)^ Trubar's choice was later adopted also by other Protestant writers in the 16th century, and ultimately led to a formation of a more standard language.{#cite_ref-159}  

### In literary fiction {#In_literary_fiction}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: In literary fiction")\]

Ljubljana appears in the 2005 *[The Historian](/wiki/The_Historian "The Historian")* , written by [Elisabeth Kostova](/wiki/Elisabeth_Kostova "Elisabeth Kostova"), and is called by its Roman name (Emona).^[\[159\]](#cite_note-160)^{#cite_ref-160}

Ljubljana is also the setting of [Paulo Coelho](/wiki/Paulo_Coelho "Paulo Coelho")'s 1998 novel *[Veronika Decides to Die](/wiki/Veronika_Decides_to_Die "Veronika Decides to Die")*.

During 2010, Ljubljana was designated as the [World Book Capital](/wiki/World_Book_Capital "World Book Capital") by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO").^[\[160\]](#cite_note-161)^{#cite_ref-161}  

### Festivals {#Festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Festivals")\]

Each year, over 10,000 cultural events take place in the city, including ten international theatre, music, and art festivals.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-InfoIntro2-67)^ The [Ljubljana Festival](/wiki/Ljubljana_Festival "Ljubljana Festival") is one of the two oldest festivals in former Yugoslavia (the [Dubrovnik Summer Festival](/wiki/Dubrovnik_Summer_Festival "Dubrovnik Summer Festival") was established in 1950, and the Ljubljana Festival one in 1953). Guests have included [Dubravka Tomšič](/wiki/Dubravka_Tom%C5%A1i%C4%8D "Dubravka Tomšič"), [Marjana Lipovšek](/wiki/Marjana_Lipov%C5%A1ek "Marjana Lipovšek"), [Tomaž Pandur](/wiki/Toma%C5%BE_Pandur "Tomaž Pandur"), [Katia Ricciarelli](/wiki/Katia_Ricciarelli "Katia Ricciarelli"), [Grace Bumbry](/wiki/Grace_Bumbry "Grace Bumbry"), [Yehudi Menuhin](/wiki/Yehudi_Menuhin "Yehudi Menuhin"), [Mstislav Rostropovich](/wiki/Mstislav_Rostropovich "Mstislav Rostropovich"), [José Carreras](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Carreras "José Carreras"), [Slide Hampton](/wiki/Slide_Hampton "Slide Hampton"), [Zubin Mehta](/wiki/Zubin_Mehta "Zubin Mehta"), [Vadim Repin](/wiki/Vadim_Repin "Vadim Repin"), [Valery Gergiev](/wiki/Valery_Gergiev "Valery Gergiev"), [Sir Andrew Davis](/wiki/Andrew_Davis_(conductor) "Andrew Davis (conductor)"), [Danjulo Ishizaka](/wiki/Danjulo_Ishizaka "Danjulo Ishizaka"), [Midori (violinist)](/wiki/Midori_(violinist) "Midori (violinist)"), [Yuri Bashmet](/wiki/Yuri_Bashmet "Yuri Bashmet"), [Ennio Morricone](/wiki/Ennio_Morricone "Ennio Morricone"), and [Manhattan Transfer](/wiki/The_Manhattan_Transfer "The Manhattan Transfer"). Orchestras have included the [New York Philharmonic](/wiki/New_York_Philharmonic "New York Philharmonic"), [Israel Philharmonic](/wiki/Israel_Philharmonic "Israel Philharmonic"), [Royal Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/Royal_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Royal Philharmonic Orchestra"), Orchestras of the [Bolshoi Theatre](/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre "Bolshoi Theatre") from [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow"), [La Scala](/wiki/La_Scala "La Scala") from [Milan](/wiki/Milan "Milan"), and [Mariinsky Theatre](/wiki/Mariinsky_Theatre "Mariinsky Theatre") from [Saint Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg "Saint Petersburg"). In recent years there have been 80 kinds of events and some 80,000 visitors from Slovenia and abroad.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Other cultural venues include [Križanke](/wiki/Kri%C5%BEanke "Križanke"), [Cankar Hall](/wiki/Cankar_Hall "Cankar Hall") and the [Exhibition and Convention Centre](/wiki/Exhibition_and_Convention_Centre_(Ljubljana) "Exhibition and Convention Centre (Ljubljana)"). During Book Week, starting each year on [World Book Day](/wiki/World_Book_Day "World Book Day"), events and book sales take place at [Congress Square](/wiki/Congress_Square "Congress Square"). A [flea market](/wiki/Flea_market "Flea market") is held every Sunday in the old city.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-Pointinteret2-162)^ On the evening of [International Workers' Day](/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day "International Workers' Day"), a celebration with a [bonfire](/wiki/Bonfire "Bonfire") takes place on [Rožnik Hill](/wiki/Ro%C5%BEnik_Hill "Rožnik Hill").{#cite_ref-Pointinteret2_162-0}  

### Museums and art galleries {#Museums_and_art_galleries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Museums and art galleries")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Slovenian_Railway_Museum_2010.JPG/220px-Slovenian_Railway_Museum_2010.JPG)](/wiki/File:Slovenian_Railway_Museum_2010.JPG) Interior of the Slovenian Railway Museum [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/NationalGallery-Ljubljana.JPG/220px-NationalGallery-Ljubljana.JPG)](/wiki/File:NationalGallery-Ljubljana.JPG) Main building of the Slovenian National Gallery

Ljubljana has numerous [art galleries](/wiki/Art_museum "Art museum") and museums. The first purpose-built art gallery in Ljubljana was the [Jakopič Pavilion](/wiki/Jakopi%C4%8D_Pavilion "Jakopič Pavilion"), which was in the first half of the 20th century the central exhibition venue of Slovene artists. In the early 1960s, it was succeeded by [Ljubljana City Art Gallery](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_City_Art_Gallery&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana City Art Gallery (page does not exist)"), which has presented a number of modern Slovene and foreign artists. In 2010, there were 14 museums and 56 art galleries in Ljubljana.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-InNumbers2-163)^ There is for example an architecture museum, [a railway museum](/wiki/Slovenian_Railway_Museum "Slovenian Railway Museum"), a school museum, a sports museum, a museum of modern art, a museum of contemporary art, a [brewery museum](/wiki/Pivovarna_Union "Pivovarna Union"), the [Slovenian Museum of Natural History](/wiki/Slovenian_Museum_of_Natural_History "Slovenian Museum of Natural History") and the Slovene Ethnographic Museum.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-Pointinteret2-162)^ The [National Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Slovenia "National Gallery of Slovenia") (*Narodna galerija*), founded in 1918,^[\[71\]](#cite_note-Histo52-72)^ and the [Museum of Modern Art](/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art_(Ljubljana) "Museum of Modern Art (Ljubljana)") (*Moderna galerija*) exhibit the [most influential Slovenian artists](/wiki/List_of_Slovenian_artists "List of Slovenian artists"). In 2006, the museums received 264,470 visitors, the galleries 403,890 and the theatres 396,440.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-InNumbers2-163)^ The [Metelkova Museum of Contemporary Art](/w/index.php?title=Metelkova_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art&action=edit&redlink=1 "Metelkova Museum of Contemporary Art (page does not exist)") (*Muzej sodobne umetnosti Metelkova*), opened in 2011,^[\[163\]](#cite_note-164)^ hosts simultaneous exhibitions, a research library, archives, and a bookshop. The [Škuc Gallery](/wiki/%C5%A0kuc_Gallery "Škuc Gallery") is a contemporary art gallery that opened in 1978.{#cite_ref-164}  

### Entertainment and performing arts {#Entertainment_and_performing_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Entertainment and performing arts")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Ljubljanska_Opera_2.jpg/220px-Ljubljanska_Opera_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ljubljanska_Opera_2.jpg) The front of the [Opera and Ballet Theatre](/wiki/Slovene_National_Opera_and_Ballet_Theatre "Slovene National Opera and Ballet Theatre") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/SNG-Drama-Ljubljana.JPG/220px-SNG-Drama-Ljubljana.JPG)](/wiki/File:SNG-Drama-Ljubljana.JPG) The Slovenian National Theatre

[Cankar Hall](/wiki/Cankar_Hall "Cankar Hall") is the largest Slovenian cultural and congress center with multiple halls and a large foyer in which art film festivals, artistic performances, book fairs, and other cultural events are held.  

#### Cinema {#Cinema}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Cinema")\]

The cinema in Ljubljana appeared for the first time at the turn of the 20th century, and quickly gained popularity among the residents. After World War II, the [Cinema Company Ljubljana](/w/index.php?title=Cinema_Company_Ljubljana&action=edit&redlink=1 "Cinema Company Ljubljana (page does not exist)"), later named *Ljubljana Cinematographers* , was established and managed a number of already functioning movie theatres in Ljubljana, including the only Yugoslav children's theatre. Cinema festivals took place in the 1960s, and a [cinematheque](/wiki/Cinematheque "Cinematheque") opened its doors in 1963. With the advent of television, video, and recently the Internet, most cinema theatres in Ljubljana closed, and the cinema mainly moved to [Kolosej](/w/index.php?title=Kolosej&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kolosej (page does not exist)"), a [multiplex](/wiki/Multiplex_(movie_theater) "Multiplex (movie theater)") in the [BTC City](/wiki/BTC_City "BTC City"). It features twelve screens, including an [IMAX 3D](/wiki/IMAX_3D "IMAX 3D") screen. The remaining theatres are [Kino Komuna](/w/index.php?title=Kino_Komuna&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kino Komuna (page does not exist)"), [Kinodvor](/w/index.php?title=Kinodvor&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kinodvor (page does not exist)"), where art movies are accompanied by events, and the [Slovenian Cinematheque](/w/index.php?title=Slovenian_Cinematheque&action=edit&redlink=1 "Slovenian Cinematheque (page does not exist)"). The [Slovenian Cinematheque](/w/index.php?title=Slovenian_Cinematheque&action=edit&redlink=1 "Slovenian Cinematheque (page does not exist)") hosts the international [Ljubljana LGBT Film Festival](/wiki/Ljubljana_LGBT_Film_Festival "Ljubljana LGBT Film Festival") which showcases [LGBT](/wiki/LGBT "LGBT")-themed films. Founded in 1984, it is the oldest film festival of its sort in Europe (with oldest ex SFRY LGBT+ march in [Ljubljana Pride](/wiki/Ljubljana_Pride "Ljubljana Pride")).^[\[164\]](#cite_note-165)^{#cite_ref-165}  

#### Classical music, opera and ballet {#Classical_music.2C_opera_and_ballet}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Classical music, opera and ballet")\]

The [Slovenian Philharmonics](/wiki/Slovenian_Philharmonics "Slovenian Philharmonics") is the central music institution in Ljubljana and Slovenia. It holds [classical music](/wiki/Classical_music "Classical music") concerts of domestic and foreign performers as well as educates youth. It was established in 1701 as part of [Academia operosorum Labacensis](/wiki/Academia_operosorum_Labacensis "Academia operosorum Labacensis") and is among the oldest such institutions in Europe. The [Slovene National Opera and Ballet Theatre](/wiki/Slovene_National_Opera_and_Ballet_Theatre "Slovene National Opera and Ballet Theatre") also resides in Ljubljana, presenting a wide variety of domestic and foreign, modern and classic, opera, ballet and concert works. It serves as the national opera and ballet house. Music festivals are held in Ljubljana, chiefly in [European classical music](/wiki/Classical_music "Classical music") and jazz, for instance the [Ljubljana Summer Festival](/wiki/Ljubljana_Summer_Festival "Ljubljana Summer Festival") (*Ljubljanski poletni festival*), and [Trnfest](/w/index.php?title=Trnfest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Trnfest (page does not exist)").  

#### Theatre {#Theatre}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Theatre")\]

In addition to the main houses, with the [SNT Drama Ljubljana](/wiki/Slovene_National_Theatre,_Ljubljana "Slovene National Theatre, Ljubljana") as the most important among them, a number of small producers are active in Ljubljana, involved primarily in [physical theatre](/wiki/Physical_theatre "Physical theatre") (e.g. [Betontanc](/w/index.php?title=Betontanc&action=edit&redlink=1 "Betontanc (page does not exist)")), [street theatre](/wiki/Street_theatre "Street theatre") (e.g. [Ana Monró Theatre](/w/index.php?title=Ana_Monr%C3%B3_Theatre&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ana Monró Theatre (page does not exist)")), [theatresports](/wiki/Theatresports "Theatresports") championship [Impro League](/wiki/Impro_League "Impro League"), and [improvisational theatre](/wiki/Improvisational_theatre "Improvisational theatre") (e.g. [IGLU Theatre](/wiki/IGLU_Theatre "IGLU Theatre")). A popular form is [puppetry](/wiki/Puppetry "Puppetry"), mainly performed in the [Ljubljana Puppet Theatre](/wiki/Ljubljana_Puppet_Theatre "Ljubljana Puppet Theatre"). Theatre has a rich tradition in Ljubljana, starting with the 1867 first ever Slovene-language drama performance.  

#### Modern dance {#Modern_dance}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Modern dance")\]

The [modern dance](/wiki/Modern_dance "Modern dance") was presented in Ljubljana for the first time at the end of the 19th century and developed rapidly since the end of the 1920s. Since the 1930s when in Ljubljana was founded a [Mary Wigman](/wiki/Mary_Wigman "Mary Wigman") dance school, the first one for modern dance in Slovenia, the field has been intimately linked to the development in Europe and the United States. [Ljubljana Dance Theatre](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Dance_Theatre&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana Dance Theatre (page does not exist)") is today the only venue in Ljubljana dedicated to [contemporary dance](/wiki/Contemporary_dance "Contemporary dance"). Despite this, there's a vivid happening in the field.  

#### Folk dance {#Folk_dance}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Folk dance")\]

Several [folk dance](/wiki/Folk_dance "Folk dance") groups are active in Ljubljana.  

#### Jazz {#Jazz}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Jazz")\]

In July 2015, the 56th Ljubljana Jazz Festival was held. A participant event in the European Jazz Network, the festival took place over four days and included 19 concerts with artists from 19 countries, including a celebration of the 75th birthday of [James "Blood" Ulmer](/wiki/James_%22Blood%22_Ulmer "James \"Blood\" Ulmer").^[\[165\]](#cite_note-166)^{#cite_ref-166}  

### Popular urban culture and alternative scene {#Popular_urban_culture_and_alternative_scene}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Popular urban culture and alternative scene")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/20190510_KinoSiska_01_PhotoNejcKetis.jpg/220px-20190510_KinoSiska_01_PhotoNejcKetis.jpg)](/wiki/File:20190510_KinoSiska_01_PhotoNejcKetis.jpg) [Kino Šiška Centre for Urban Culture](/w/index.php?title=Kino_%C5%A0i%C5%A1ka_Centre_for_Urban_Culture&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kino Šiška Centre for Urban Culture (page does not exist)") in Ljubljana [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Metelkova_mesto6.jpg/220px-Metelkova_mesto6.jpg)](/wiki/File:Metelkova_mesto6.jpg) *The Barn* building located in [Metelkova](/wiki/Metelkova "Metelkova"), the Ljubljana equivalent of the Copenhagen's [Freetown Christiania](/wiki/Freetown_Christiania "Freetown Christiania").

In the 1980s with the emergence of [subcultures](/wiki/Subculture "Subculture") in Ljubljana, an alternative culture began to develop in Ljubljana organised around two student organisations.^[\[166\]](#cite_note-167)^ This caused an influx of young people to the city centre, caused political and social changes, and led to the establishment of alternative art centres.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-168)^{#cite_ref-168}


Metelkova and Rog

A Ljubljana equivalent of Copenhagen's [Freetown Christiania](/wiki/Freetown_Christiania "Freetown Christiania"), a self-proclaimed autonomous [Metelkova](/wiki/Metelkova "Metelkova") neighbourhood, was set up in a former Austro-Hungarian barracks that was built in 1882.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-Metelkova2-169)^^[\[169\]](#cite_note-Metelkova_mesto2-170)^{#cite_ref-Metelkova_mesto2_170-0}

In 1993, the seven buildings and 12,500 square metres (135,000 sq ft) of space were turned into art galleries, artist studios, and seven nightclubs, including two LGBTQ+ venues, playing host to music from hardcore to jazz to dub to techno. Celica Hostel is adjacent to Metelkova^[\[170\]](#cite_note-CelicaHostel2-171)^ with rooms artistically decorated by Metelkova artists. A new part of the Museum of Modern Art is the nearby Museum of Contemporary Art.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-CalgaryHerald2-172)^ Another alternative culture centre is located in the former [Rog factory](/wiki/Rog_(factory) "Rog (factory)"). Both [Metelkova](/wiki/Metelkova "Metelkova") and the [Rog factory](/wiki/Rog_(factory) "Rog (factory)") complex are near the city centre.{#cite_ref-CalgaryHerald2_172-0}

In 2023, the Rog factory underwent a complete renovation and rebranding, and it is now known as Center Rog. Center Rog has nineteen project studios and five residential apartments in addition to a new branch of the Ljubljana City Library (Rog Library), a large exhibition and event hall, a café, bistro, and restaurant, and several shops with local products.^[\[172\]](#cite_note-173)^{#cite_ref-173}


Šiška Cultural Quarter

Šiška Cultural Quarter hosts art groups and cultural organisations dedicated to contemporary and avant-garde arts. [Kino Šiška Centre for Urban Culture](/w/index.php?title=Kino_%C5%A0i%C5%A1ka_Centre_for_Urban_Culture&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kino Šiška Centre for Urban Culture (page does not exist)") is there, a venue offering concerts of indie, punk, and rock bands as well as exhibitions take place. The Museum of Transitory Art (MoTA) is a museum without a permanent collection or a fixed space. Its programs are realised in temporary physical and virtual spaces dedicated to advancing the research, production and presentation of transitory, experimental, and live art forms. Yearly MoTA organises the Sonica Festival. Ljudmila (since 1994), which strives to connect research practices, technologies, science, and art.  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Sports")\]  

### Clubs {#Clubs}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Clubs")\]

Tension between German and Slovene residents dominated the development of sport in Ljubljana in the 19th century. The first sports club in Ljubljana was the [South Sokol Gymnastic Club](/w/index.php?title=South_Sokol_Gymnastic_Club&action=edit&redlink=1 "South Sokol Gymnastic Club (page does not exist)") (*Gimnastično društvo Južni Sokol*), established in 1863 and succeeded in 1868 by the [Ljubljana Sokol](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Sokol&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana Sokol (page does not exist)") (*Ljubljanski Sokol*). It was the parent club of all [Slovene Sokol clubs](/wiki/Slovene_Sokol_movement "Slovene Sokol movement") as well as an encouragement for the establishment of the [Croatian Sokol club](/wiki/Croatian_Sokol_movement "Croatian Sokol movement") in Zagreb. Members were also active in culture and politics, striving for greater integration of the Slovenes from different Crown lands of [Austria-Hungary](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary") and for their cultural, political, and economic independence.

In 1885, German residents established the first sports club in the territory of nowadays Slovenia, *[Der Laibacher Byciklistischer Club](/w/index.php?title=Der_Laibacher_Byciklistischer_Club&action=edit&redlink=1 "Der Laibacher Byciklistischer Club (page does not exist)")* (*Ljubljana Cycling Club* ). In 1887, Slovene cyclists established the [Slovene Cyclists Club](/w/index.php?title=Slovene_Cyclists_Club&action=edit&redlink=1 "Slovene Cyclists Club (page does not exist)") (*Slovenski biciklistični klub*). In 1893 followed the first Slovene [Alpine club](/wiki/Alpine_club "Alpine club"), named [Slovene Alpine Club](/w/index.php?title=Slovene_Alpine_Club&action=edit&redlink=1 "Slovene Alpine Club (page does not exist)") (*Slovensko planinsko društvo*), later succeeded by the [Alpine Association of Slovenia](/wiki/Alpine_Association_of_Slovenia "Alpine Association of Slovenia") (*Planinska zveza Slovenije*). Several of its branches operate in Ljubljana, the largest of them being the [Ljubljana Matica Alpine Club](/wiki/Ljubljana_Matica_Alpine_Club "Ljubljana Matica Alpine Club") (*Planinsko društvo Ljubljana-Matica*). In 1900, the sports club *Laibacher Sportverein* (English: *Ljubljana Sports Club* ) was established by the city's German residents and functioned until 1909. In 1906, Slovenes organised themselves in its Slovene counterpart, the Ljubljana Sports Club (*Ljubljanski športni klub*). Its members were primarily interested in [rowing](/wiki/Rowing_(sport) "Rowing (sport)"), but also swimming and football. In 1911, the first Slovenian football club, [Ilirija](/wiki/ND_Ilirija "ND Ilirija"), started operating in the city. Winter sports already started to develop in the area of the nowadays Ljubljana before World War II.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-SDDolomiti2012-01-052-174)^ In 1929, the first [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") club in Slovenia (then Yugoslavia), [SK Ilirija](/wiki/HDD_Olimpija_Ljubljana "HDD Olimpija Ljubljana"), was established.{#cite_ref-SDDolomiti2012-01-052_174-0}

Nowadays, the [city's football](/wiki/Football_in_Ljubljana "Football in Ljubljana") teams which play in the [Slovenian PrvaLiga](/wiki/Slovenian_PrvaLiga "Slovenian PrvaLiga") are [NK Olimpija Ljubljana](/wiki/NK_Olimpija_Ljubljana "NK Olimpija Ljubljana") and [NK Bravo](/wiki/NK_Bravo "NK Bravo"). [ND Ilirija 1911](/wiki/ND_Ilirija_1911 "ND Ilirija 1911") currently competes in [Slovenian Second League](/wiki/Slovenian_Second_League "Slovenian Second League"). Ljubljana's [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") clubs are [HK Slavija](/wiki/HK_Slavija_Ljubljana "HK Slavija Ljubljana") and [HK Olimpija](/wiki/HK_Olimpija "HK Olimpija"). They both compete in the [Slovenian Hockey League](/wiki/Slovenian_Ice_Hockey_League "Slovenian Ice Hockey League"). The basketball teams are [KD Slovan](/wiki/KD_Slovan "KD Slovan"), [KD Ilirija](/wiki/KD_Ilirija "KD Ilirija") and [KK Cedevita Olimpija](/wiki/KK_Cedevita_Olimpija "KK Cedevita Olimpija"). The latter, which has a green dragon as its mascot, hosts its matches at the 12,480-seat [Arena Stožice](/wiki/Arena_Sto%C5%BEice "Arena Stožice"). [Ježica](/wiki/%C5%BDKD_Je%C5%BEica "ŽKD Ježica") is women's basketball that competes in [Slovenian League](/wiki/Slovenian_Women%27s_Basketball_League "Slovenian Women's Basketball League"). The [Ljubljana Silverhawks](/wiki/Ljubljana_Silverhawks "Ljubljana Silverhawks") represented the city in American football. Handball is popular in the female section. [RK Krim](/wiki/RK_Krim "RK Krim") is one of the best women's handball teams in Europe. They won the [EHF Champions League](/wiki/EHF_Champions_League "EHF Champions League") twice, in 2001 and 2003.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-175)^ [RD Slovan](/wiki/RD_Slovan "RD Slovan") is male handball club from Ljubljana that currently competes in [Slovenian First League](/wiki/Slovenian_First_League_(men%27s_handball) "Slovenian First League (men's handball)"). [AMTK Ljubljana](/wiki/AMTK_Ljubljana "AMTK Ljubljana") is the most successful [speedway](/wiki/Motorcycle_speedway "Motorcycle speedway") club in Slovenia. The Ljubljana Sports Club has been succeeded by the [Livada Canoe and Kayak Club](/w/index.php?title=Livada_Canoe_and_Kayak_Club&action=edit&redlink=1 "Livada Canoe and Kayak Club (page does not exist)").^[\[175\]](#cite_note-Habič1997SPM2-176)^{#cite_ref-Habič1997SPM2_176-0}  

### Mass sport activities {#Mass_sport_activities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Mass sport activities")\]

Each year since 1957, on 8--10 May, the recreational *[Walk Along the Wire](/wiki/Trail_of_Remembrance_and_Comradeship "Trail of Remembrance and Comradeship")* has taken place to mark the liberation of Ljubljana on 9 May 1945.^[\[176\]](#cite_note-177)^ At the same occasion, a triples competition is run on the trail, and a few days later, a student-run from Prešeren Square to Ljubljana Castle is held. The last Sunday in October, the [Ljubljana Marathon](/wiki/Ljubljana_Marathon "Ljubljana Marathon") and a few minor competition runs take place on the city streets. The event attracts several thousand runners each year.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-178)^{#cite_ref-178}  

### Sport venues {#Sport_venues}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Sport venues")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Tacen_Whitewater_Course_2.jpg/220px-Tacen_Whitewater_Course_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tacen_Whitewater_Course_2.jpg) The [Tacen Whitewater Course](/wiki/Tacen_Whitewater_Course "Tacen Whitewater Course") on the Sava

The [Stožice Stadium](/wiki/Sto%C5%BEice_Stadium "Stožice Stadium"), opened in August 2010 and located in [Stožice Sports Park](/wiki/Sto%C5%BEice_Sports_Park "Stožice Sports Park") in the [Bežigrad District](/wiki/Be%C5%BEigrad_District "Bežigrad District"), is the biggest football stadium in the country and the home of the NK Olimpija Ljubljana. It is one of the two main venues of the [Slovenia national football team](/wiki/Slovenia_national_football_team "Slovenia national football team"). The park also has an indoor arena, used for indoor sports such as basketball, [handball](/wiki/Team_handball "Team handball") and [volleyball](/wiki/Volleyball "Volleyball") and is the home venue of [KK Olimpija](/wiki/KK_Olimpija "KK Olimpija"), [RK Krim](/wiki/RK_Krim "RK Krim") and [ACH Volley Bled](/wiki/ACH_Volley_Bled "ACH Volley Bled") among others. Besides football, the stadium is designed to host cultural events as well. Another stadium in the Bežigrad district, [Bežigrad Stadium](/wiki/Be%C5%BEigrad_Stadium "Bežigrad Stadium"), is closed since 2008 and is deteriorating. It was built according to the plans of [Jože Plečnik](/wiki/Jo%C5%BEe_Ple%C4%8Dnik "Jože Plečnik") and was the home of the [NK Olimpija Ljubljana](/wiki/NK_Olimpija_Ljubljana_(1911%E2%80%932004) "NK Olimpija Ljubljana (1911–2004)"), dissolved in 2004. [Joc Pečečnik](/w/index.php?title=Joc_Pe%C4%8De%C4%8Dnik&action=edit&redlink=1 "Joc Pečečnik (page does not exist)"), a Slovenian multimillionaire, plans to renovate it.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-179)^{#cite_ref-179}

[Šiška Sports Park](/wiki/%C5%A0i%C5%A1ka_Sports_Park "Šiška Sports Park") is located in [Spodnja Šiška](/wiki/Spodnja_%C5%A0i%C5%A1ka "Spodnja Šiška"), part of the [Šiška District](/wiki/%C5%A0i%C5%A1ka_District "Šiška District"). It has a football stadium with five courts, an athletic hall, outdoor athletic areas, tennis courts, a [Boules](/wiki/Boules "Boules") court, and a [sand volleyball](/wiki/Sand_volleyball "Sand volleyball") court. The majority of competitions are in [athletics](/wiki/Athletics_(sport) "Athletics (sport)"). Another sports park in Spodnja Šiška is [Ilirija Sports Park](/wiki/Ilirija_Sports_Park "Ilirija Sports Park"), known primarily for its stadium with a speedway track. At the northern end of Tivoli Park stands the [Ilirija Swimming Pool Complex](/w/index.php?title=Ilirija_Swimming_Pool_Complex&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ilirija Swimming Pool Complex (page does not exist)"), which was built as part of a swimming and athletics venue following plans by Bloudek in the 1930s and has been nearly abandoned since then, but there are plans to renovate it.

A number of sport venues are located in Tivoli Park. An outdoor swimming pool in Tivoli, constructed by Bloudek in 1929, was the first [Olympic-size swimming pool](/wiki/Olympic-size_swimming_pool "Olympic-size swimming pool") in Yugoslavia. The [Tivoli Recreational Centre](/w/index.php?title=Tivoli_Recreational_Centre&action=edit&redlink=1 "Tivoli Recreational Centre (page does not exist)") in Tivoli is Ljubljana's largest recreational centre and has three swimming pools, saunas, a Boules court, a health club, and other facilities.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-180)^ There are two skating rinks, a basketball court, a winter ice rink, and ten tennis courts in its outdoor area.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-181)^ The [Tivoli Hall](/wiki/Tivoli_Hall "Tivoli Hall") consists of two halls. The smaller one accepts 4,050 spectators and is used for basketball matches. The larger one can accommodate 6,000 spectators and is primarily used for hockey, but also for basketball matches. The halls are also used for concerts and other cultural events. The [Slovenian Olympic Committee](/wiki/Slovenian_Olympic_Committee "Slovenian Olympic Committee") has its office in the building.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-182)^{#cite_ref-182}

The [Tacen Whitewater Course](/wiki/Tacen_Whitewater_Course "Tacen Whitewater Course"), located on a course on the Sava, 8 km (5 mi) northwest of the city centre, hosts a major international canoe/kayak slalom competition almost every year, examples being the [ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships](/wiki/ICF_Canoe_Slalom_World_Championships "ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships") in [1955](/wiki/1955_ICF_Canoe_Slalom_World_Championships "1955 ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships"), [1991](/wiki/1991_ICF_Canoe_Slalom_World_Championships "1991 ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships"), and [2010](/wiki/2010_ICF_Canoe_Slalom_World_Championships "2010 ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships").^[\[182\]](#cite_note-183)^{#cite_ref-183}

Since the 1940s,^[\[173\]](#cite_note-SDDolomiti2012-01-052-174)^ a [ski slope](/wiki/Ski_slope "Ski slope") has been in use in [Gunclje](/wiki/Gunclje "Gunclje"),^[\[183\]](#cite_note-APG2012-05-02OP2-184)^ in the northwestern part of the city.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-185)^ It is 600 m (2,000 ft) long and has two ski lifts, its maximum incline is 60° and the difference in height from the top to the bottom is 155 m (509 ft).^[\[183\]](#cite_note-APG2012-05-02OP2-184)^ Five [ski jumping hills](/wiki/Ski_jumping_hill "Ski jumping hill") stand near the ski slope.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-SDDolomiti2012-01-052-174)^ Several Slovenian Olympic and World Cup medalists trained and competed there.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-SDDolomiti2012-01-052-174)^^[\[185\]](#cite_note-186)^ In addition, the Arena Triglav complex of six jumping hills is located in the [Šiška District](/wiki/%C5%A0i%C5%A1ka_District "Šiška District").^[\[186\]](#cite_note-187)^^[\[187\]](#cite_note-188)^ A ski jumping hill, built in 1954 to plans by [Stanko Bloudek](/wiki/Stanko_Bloudek "Stanko Bloudek"), was located in Šiška near [Vodnik Street](/w/index.php?title=Vodnik_Street&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vodnik Street (page does not exist)") (*Vodnikova cesta*) until 1976. International competitions for the [Kongsberg Cup](/w/index.php?title=Kongsberg_Cup&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kongsberg Cup (page does not exist)") were held there, attended by thousands of spectators.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-189)^ The ice rinks in Ljubljana include [Koseze Pond](/wiki/Koseze_Pond "Koseze Pond") and Tivoli Hall. In addition, in the 19th century and the early 20th century, [Tivoli Pond](/wiki/Tivoli_Pond "Tivoli Pond") and a marshy meadow in [Trnovo](/wiki/Trnovo,_Ljubljana "Trnovo, Ljubljana"), named Kern, were used for ice skating.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-190)^{#cite_ref-190}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Economy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/BTC_City_panorama.jpg/220px-BTC_City_panorama.jpg)](/wiki/File:BTC_City_panorama.jpg) [BTC City](/wiki/BTC_City "BTC City") is the largest shopping mall, sports, entertainment, and business area in Ljubljana

Industry is the most important employer, notably in the [pharmaceuticals](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry "Pharmaceutical industry"), [petrochemicals](/wiki/Petrochemical "Petrochemical") and [food processing](/wiki/Food_industry "Food industry").^[\[66\]](#cite_note-InfoIntro2-67)^ Other fields include banking, finance, transport, construction, skilled trades and services and tourism. The public sector provides jobs in education, culture, [health care](/wiki/Health_care "Health care") and local administration.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-InfoIntro2-67)^{#cite_ref-InfoIntro2_67-3}

The [Ljubljana Stock Exchange](/wiki/Ljubljana_Stock_Exchange "Ljubljana Stock Exchange") (*Ljubljanska borza*), purchased in 2008 by the [Vienna Stock Exchange](/wiki/Wiener_B%C3%B6rse "Wiener Börse")^[\[190\]](#cite_note-Bourse_Vienne2-191)^ and later by the [Zagreb Stock Exchange](/wiki/Zagreb_Stock_Exchange "Zagreb Stock Exchange"), deals with large Slovenian companies. Some of these have their headquarters in the capital: for example, the [retail chain](/wiki/Chain_store "Chain store") [Mercator](/wiki/Mercator_(retail) "Mercator (retail)"), the [oil company](/wiki/Petroleum_industry "Petroleum industry") [Petrol d.d.](/wiki/Petrol_d.d. "Petrol d.d.") and the telecommunications concern [Telekom Slovenije](/wiki/Telekom_Slovenije "Telekom Slovenije").^[\[191\]](#cite_note-Bourse_Ljubljana2-192)^ Over 15,000 enterprises operate in the city, most of them in the [tertiary sector](/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy "Tertiary sector of the economy").^[\[192\]](#cite_note-Tertiaire_Ljubljana2-193)^{#cite_ref-Tertiaire_Ljubljana2_193-0}

Numerous companies and over 450 shops are located in the [BTC City](/wiki/BTC_City "BTC City"), the largest business, shopping, recreational, entertainment and cultural centre in Slovenia. It is visited each year by 21 million people.^[\[193\]](#cite_note-194)^^[\[194\]](#cite_note-195)^ It occupies an area of 475,000 m^2^ (5,110,000 sq ft) in the [Moste District](/wiki/Moste,_Ljubljana "Moste, Ljubljana") in the eastern part of Ljubljana.^[\[195\]](#cite_note-196)^^[\[196\]](#cite_note-197)^^[\[197\]](#cite_note-198)^{#cite_ref-198}

About 74% of Ljubljana households use [district heating](/wiki/District_heating "District heating") from the [Ljubljana Power Station](/wiki/Ljubljana_Power_Station "Ljubljana Power Station").^[\[198\]](#cite_note-199)^{#cite_ref-199}  

Government {#Government}
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Government")\]

The city of Ljubljana is governed by the [City Municipality of Ljubljana](/wiki/City_Municipality_of_Ljubljana "City Municipality of Ljubljana") ([Slovene](/wiki/Slovene_language "Slovene language"): *Mestna občina Ljubljana* ; MOL), which is led by the city council. The president of the city council is called the mayor. Members of the city council and the mayor are elected in the local election, held every four years. Among other roles, the city council drafts the municipal budget, and is assisted by various boards active in the fields of health, sports, finances, education, [environmental protection](/wiki/Environmental_movement "Environmental movement") and tourism.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-Commissions2-200)^ The municipality is subdivided into 17 districts represented by district councils. They work with the municipality council to make known residents' suggestions and prepare activities in their territories.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-Districts2-201)^^[\[201\]](#cite_note-202)^{#cite_ref-202}

Between 2002 and 2006, [Danica Simšič](/w/index.php?title=Danica_Sim%C5%A1i%C4%8D&action=edit&redlink=1 "Danica Simšič (page does not exist)") was mayor of the municipality.^[\[202\]](#cite_note-203)^ Since the municipal elections of 22 October 2006 until his confirmation as a deputy in the [National Assembly of Slovenian](/wiki/National_Assembly_(Slovenia) "National Assembly (Slovenia)") in December 2011, [Zoran Janković](/wiki/Zoran_Jankovi%C4%87_(politician) "Zoran Janković (politician)"), previously the managing director of the [Mercator retail chain](/wiki/Mercator_(retail) "Mercator (retail)"), was the mayor of Ljubljana. In 2006, he won 62.99% of the popular vote.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-Maire2-204)^ On 10 October 2010, Janković was re-elected for another four-year term with 64.79% of the vote. From 2006 until October 2010, the majority on the city council (the [Zoran Janković List](/wiki/Zoran_Jankovi%C4%87_List "Zoran Janković List")) held 23 of 45 seats.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-Maire2-204)^ On 10 October 2010, Janković's list won 25 out of 45 seats in the city council. From December 2011 onwards, when Janković's list won the [early parliamentary election](/wiki/Slovenian_parliamentary_election,_2011 "Slovenian parliamentary election, 2011"), the deputy mayor [Aleš Čerin](/wiki/Ale%C5%A1_%C4%8Cerin "Aleš Čerin") was decided by him to lead the municipality. Čerin did not hold the post of mayor.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-Dnevnik2012-02-012-205)^ After Janković had failed to be elected as the Prime Minister in the [National Assembly](/wiki/National_Assembly_(Slovenia) "National Assembly (Slovenia)"), he participated at the mayoral by-election on 25 March 2012 and was elected for the third time with 61% of the vote. He retook the leadership of the city council on 11 April 2012.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-206)^{#cite_ref-206}

Public order in Ljubljana is enforced by the [Ljubljana Police Directorate](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Police_Directorate&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana Police Directorate (page does not exist)") (*Policijska uprava Ljubljana*).^[\[206\]](#cite_note-Police2-207)^ There are five areal police stations and four sectoral police stations in Ljubljana.^[\[207\]](#cite_note-PDL2-208)^ Public order and municipal traffic regulations are also supervised by the [city traffic wardens](/w/index.php?title=Traffic_wardens_(Ljubljana)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Traffic wardens (Ljubljana) (page does not exist)") (*Mestno redarstvo*).^[\[208\]](#cite_note-209)^ Ljubljana has a quiet and secure reputation.^[\[207\]](#cite_note-PDL2-208)^^[\[209\]](#cite_note-securite2-210)^{#cite_ref-securite2_210-0}  

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------
