[Historical population]

In 1869, Ljubljana had about 22,600 inhabitants,^[\[210\]](#cite_note-Pipp2-211)^ a figure that grew to almost 60,000 by 1931.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-Histo52-72)^{#cite_ref-Histo52_72-4}

As of the 2022 census, Ljubljana had a population of 293,218 in the city proper.^[\[215\]](#cite_note-216)^^[\[216\]](#cite_note-217)^{#cite_ref-217}

At the 2002 census, 39% of Ljubljana inhabitants were [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic "Catholic"); 30% had no religion, an unknown religion or did not reply; 19% atheist; 6% [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox "Eastern Orthodox"); 5% [Muslim](/wiki/Islam "Islam"); and the remaining 0.7% Protestant or another religion.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-Religion2-218)^{#cite_ref-Religion2_218-0}

Approximately 91% of the population speaks Slovene as their primary native language. The second most-spoken language is [Bosnian](/wiki/Bosnian_language "Bosnian language"), with [Serbo-Croatian](/wiki/Serbo-Croatian "Serbo-Croatian") being the third most-spoken language.^[\[218\]](#cite_note-219)^{#cite_ref-219}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Education")\]  

### Primary education {#Primary_education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: Primary education")\]

In Ljubljana today there are over 50 public elementary schools with over 20,000 pupils.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-InNumbers2-163)^^[\[219\]](#cite_note-University_of_Ljubljana2-220)^ This also includes an [international](/wiki/International_school "International school") elementary school for foreign pupils. There are two private elementary schools: a [Waldorf](/wiki/Waldorf_education "Waldorf education") elementary school and a [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_school "Catholic school") elementary school. In addition, there are several elementary music schools.{#cite_ref-University_of_Ljubljana2_220-0}

Historically the first school in Ljubljana belonged to [Teutonic Knights](/wiki/Teutonic_Knights "Teutonic Knights") and was established in the 13th century. It originally accepted only boys; girls were accepted from the beginning of the 16th century. [Parochial schools](/wiki/Parochial_school "Parochial school") are attested in the 13th century, at [St. Peter's Church](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Parish_Church_(Ljubljana) "St. Peter's Parish Church (Ljubljana)") and at Saint Nicholas's Church, the later Ljubljana Cathedral. Since 1291, there were also trade-oriented private schools in Ljubljana. At the beginning of the 17th century, there were six schools in Ljubljana and later three. A girls' school was established by [Poor Clares](/wiki/Poor_Clares "Poor Clares"), followed in 1703 by the [Ursulines](/wiki/Ursulines "Ursulines"). Their school was for about 170 years the only public girls' school in [Carniola](/wiki/Carniola "Carniola"). These schools were mainly private or established by the city.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-221)^{#cite_ref-221}

In 1775, the Austrian Empress [Maria Theresa](/wiki/Maria_Theresa "Maria Theresa") proclaimed [elementary education](/wiki/Elementary_education "Elementary education") obligatory and Ljubljana got its [normal school](/wiki/Normal_school#Europe "Normal school"), intended as a learning place for teachers. In 1805, the first state [music school](/wiki/Music_school "Music school") was established in Ljubljana. In the time of [Illyrian Provinces](/wiki/Illyrian_Provinces "Illyrian Provinces"), "*école primaire*", a unified four-year elementary school program with a greater emphasis on Slovene, was introduced. The first public schools, unrelated to religious education, appeared in 1868.  

### Secondary education {#Secondary_education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=49 "Edit section: Secondary education")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Realka-Ljubljana.JPG/220px-Realka-Ljubljana.JPG)](/wiki/File:Realka-Ljubljana.JPG) The first complete *Realschule* (technical grammar school) was established in Ljubljana in 1871.

In Ljubljana, there are ten public and three private [grammar schools](/wiki/Grammar_school "Grammar school"). The public schools are divided into general [gymnasiums](/wiki/Gymnasium_(school) "Gymnasium (school)") and [classical](/wiki/Classical_gymnasium "Classical gymnasium") gymnasiums, the latter offering Latin and Greek as foreign languages. Some general schools offer internationally oriented European departments, and some offer sports departments, allowing students to more easily adjust their sport and school obligations. All state schools are free, but the number of students they can accept is limited. The private secondary schools include a Catholic grammar school and a Waldorf grammar school. There are also professional grammar schools in Ljubljana, offering economical, technical, or artistic subjects (visual arts, music). All grammar schools last four years and conclude with the *[matura](/wiki/Matura "Matura")* exam.

Historically, upon a proposal by [Primož Trubar](/wiki/Primo%C5%BE_Trubar "Primož Trubar"), the [Carniolan Estates' School](/w/index.php?title=Carniolan_Estates%27_School&action=edit&redlink=1 "Carniolan Estates' School (page does not exist)") (1563--1598) was established in 1563 in the period of [Slovene Reformation](/w/index.php?title=Slovene_Reformation&action=edit&redlink=1 "Slovene Reformation (page does not exist)"). Its teaching languages were mainly [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") and [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"), but also [German](/wiki/German_language "German language") and [Slovene](/wiki/Slovene_language "Slovene language"), and it was open for both sexes and all social strata. In 1597, [Jesuits](/wiki/Jesuit "Jesuit") established the [Jesuit College](/w/index.php?title=Laibach_Jesuit_College&action=edit&redlink=1 "Laibach Jesuit College (page does not exist)") (1597--1773), intended to transmit general education. In 1773, secondary education came under the control of the state. A number of reforms were implemented in the 19th century; there was more emphasis on general knowledge and religious education was removed from state secondary schools. In 1910, there were 29 secondary schools in Ljubljana, among them classical and real gymnasiums and [Realschules](/wiki/Realschule "Realschule") (technical secondary schools).  

### Tertiary education {#Tertiary_education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=50 "Edit section: Tertiary education")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/University_of_Ljubljana_Palace.jpg/220px-University_of_Ljubljana_Palace.jpg)](/wiki/File:University_of_Ljubljana_Palace.jpg) The main building of the [University of Ljubljana](/wiki/University_of_Ljubljana "University of Ljubljana"), formerly the seat of the Carniolan Parliament

In 2011, the University had 23 faculties and three academies, located around Ljubljana. They offer Slovene-language courses in medicine, [applied sciences](/wiki/Applied_science "Applied science"), arts, law, administration, natural sciences, and other subjects.^[\[221\]](#cite_note-Université_Ljubljana_II2-222)^ The university has more than 63,000 students and some 4,000 teaching faculty.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-University_of_Ljubljana2-220)^ Students make up one-seventh of Ljubljana's population, giving the city a youthful character.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-University_of_Ljubljana2-220)^^[\[222\]](#cite_note-Université_Ljubljana2-223)^{#cite_ref-Université_Ljubljana2_223-0}

Historically, higher schools offering the study of general medicine, surgery, architecture, law and theology, started to operate in Ljubljana under the [French annexation of Slovene territory](/wiki/Illyrian_Provinces "Illyrian Provinces"), in 1810--1811. The Austro-Hungarian Empire never allowed Slovenes to establish their own university in Ljubljana, and the [University of Ljubljana](/wiki/University_of_Ljubljana "University of Ljubljana"), Slovenia's most important university, was founded in 1919 after Slovenes joined the first Yugoslavia.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-Histo52-72)^^[\[219\]](#cite_note-University_of_Ljubljana2-220)^ When it was founded, the university comprised five faculties: law, philosophy, technology, theology and medicine. From the beginning, the seat of the university has been at [Congress Square](/wiki/Congress_Square "Congress Square") in a building that served as the State Mansion of Carniola from 1902 to 1918.{#cite_ref-University_of_Ljubljana2_220-3}  

### Libraries {#Libraries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=51 "Edit section: Libraries")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b6/National_Library_Ljubljana_2010.jpg/220px-National_Library_Ljubljana_2010.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_Library_Ljubljana_2010.jpg) The building of the [National and University Library](/wiki/National_and_University_Library_of_Slovenia "National and University Library of Slovenia"), designed in the 1930s by [Jože Plečnik](/wiki/Jo%C5%BEe_Ple%C4%8Dnik "Jože Plečnik")


National and University Library of Slovenia

The [National and University Library of Slovenia](/wiki/National_and_University_Library_of_Slovenia "National and University Library of Slovenia") is the Slovene [national](/wiki/National_library "National library") and [university library](/wiki/University_library "University library"). In 2011, it held about 1,307,000 books, 8,700 manuscripts, and numerous other textual, visual and multimedia resources, altogether 2,657,000 volumes.^[\[223\]](#cite_note-PP20112-224)^{#cite_ref-PP20112_224-0}


Central Technological Library

The second largest university library in Ljubljana is the [Central Technological Library](/w/index.php?title=Central_Technological_Library&action=edit&redlink=1 "Central Technological Library (page does not exist)"), the national library and information hub for natural sciences and technology.


Municipal Library and other libraries

The Municipal [City Library of Ljubljana](/w/index.php?title=City_Library_of_Ljubljana&action=edit&redlink=1 "City Library of Ljubljana (page does not exist)"), established in 2008, is the central regional library and the largest Slovenian general public library. In 2011, it held 1,657,000 volumes, among these 1,432,000 books and a multitude of other resources in 36 branches.^[\[224\]](#cite_note-225)^ Altogether, there are 5 general public libraries and over 140 specialised libraries in Ljubljana.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-InNumbers2-163)^{#cite_ref-InNumbers2_163-3}

Besides the two largest university libraries there are libraries at individual faculties, departments and institutes of the [University of Ljubljana](/wiki/University_of_Ljubljana "University of Ljubljana"). The largest among them are the [Central Humanist Library](/w/index.php?title=Central_Humanist_Library_of_the_Faculty_of_Arts&action=edit&redlink=1 "Central Humanist Library of the Faculty of Arts (page does not exist)") in the field of [humanities](/wiki/Humanities "Humanities"), the [Central Social Sciences Library](/w/index.php?title=Central_Social_Sciences_Library_of_the_Faculty_of_Social_Sciences,_Ljubljana&action=edit&redlink=1 "Central Social Sciences Library of the Faculty of Social Sciences, Ljubljana (page does not exist)"), the [Central Economic Library](/w/index.php?title=Central_Economic_Library&action=edit&redlink=1 "Central Economic Library (page does not exist)") in the field of [economics](/wiki/Economics "Economics"), the [Central Medical Library](/w/index.php?title=Central_Medical_Library&action=edit&redlink=1 "Central Medical Library (page does not exist)") in the field of [medical sciences](/wiki/Medical_sciences "Medical sciences"), and the [Libraries of the Biotechnical Faculty](/w/index.php?title=Libraries_of_the_Biotechnical_Faculty&action=edit&redlink=1 "Libraries of the Biotechnical Faculty (page does not exist)") in the field of [biology](/wiki/Biology "Biology") and [biotechnology](/wiki/Biotechnology "Biotechnology").^[\[225\]](#cite_note-226)^{#cite_ref-226}


History

The first libraries in Ljubljana were located in [monasteries](/wiki/Monastery "Monastery"). The first public library was the [Carniolan Estates' Library](/w/index.php?title=Carniolan_Estates%27_Library&action=edit&redlink=1 "Carniolan Estates' Library (page does not exist)"), established in 1569 by Primož Trubar. In the 17th century, the [Jesuit Library](/w/index.php?title=Jesuit_library,_Ljubljana&action=edit&redlink=1 "Jesuit library, Ljubljana (page does not exist)") collected numerous works, particularly about mathematics. In 1707, the [Seminary Library](/w/index.php?title=Seminary_Library,_Ljubljana&action=edit&redlink=1 "Seminary Library, Ljubljana (page does not exist)") was established; it is the first and oldest public scientific library in Slovenia. Around 1774, after the dissolution of the Jesuits, the [Lyceum Library](/w/index.php?title=Lyceum_Library,_Ljubljana&action=edit&redlink=1 "Lyceum Library, Ljubljana (page does not exist)") was formed from the remains of the Jesuit Library as well as several monastery libraries.  

Science {#Science}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=52 "Edit section: Science")\]

The first society of the leading scientists and public workers in Carniola was the [Dismas Fraternity](/w/index.php?title=Dismas_Fraternity&action=edit&redlink=1 "Dismas Fraternity (page does not exist)") (Latin: *Societas Unitorum*), formed in Ljubljana in 1688.^[\[226\]](#cite_note-227)^ In 1693, the *[Academia Operosorum Labacensium](/wiki/Academia_Operosorum_Labacensium "Academia Operosorum Labacensium")* was founded and lasted with an interruption until the end of the 18th century. The next academy in Ljubljana, the [Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts](/wiki/Slovenian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts "Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts"), was not established until 1938.{#cite_ref-227}  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=53 "Edit section: Transport")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/ZelezniskaPostaja-Ljubljana.JPG/220px-ZelezniskaPostaja-Ljubljana.JPG)](/wiki/File:ZelezniskaPostaja-Ljubljana.JPG) [Ljubljana Bus Station](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Bus_Station&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana Bus Station (page does not exist)") and the building of the [Ljubljana Railway Station](/wiki/Ljubljana_Railway_Station "Ljubljana Railway Station") in the background [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Trains_pic_by_Praktica.JPG/220px-Trains_pic_by_Praktica.JPG)](/wiki/File:Trains_pic_by_Praktica.JPG) Railway near the central workshop in [Moste](/wiki/Moste,_Ljubljana "Moste, Ljubljana")  

### Air transport {#Air_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=54 "Edit section: Air transport")\]

[Ljubljana Jože Pučnik Airport](/wiki/Ljubljana_Jo%C5%BEe_Pu%C4%8Dnik_Airport "Ljubljana Jože Pučnik Airport") ([ICAO](/wiki/ICAO_airport_code "ICAO airport code") code LJLJ; IATA code LJU), located 26 km (16 mi) northwest of the city, has flights to numerous European destinations. Among the companies that fly from there are [Air France](/wiki/Air_France "Air France"), [Air Serbia](/wiki/Air_Serbia "Air Serbia"), [Brussels Airlines](/wiki/Brussels_Airlines "Brussels Airlines"), [easyJet](/wiki/EasyJet "EasyJet"), [Finnair](/wiki/Finnair "Finnair"), [Lufthansa](/wiki/Lufthansa "Lufthansa"), [Swiss](/wiki/Swiss_International_Air_Lines "Swiss International Air Lines"), [Wizz Air](/wiki/Wizz_Air "Wizz Air"), [Transavia](/wiki/Transavia "Transavia") and [Turkish Airlines](/wiki/Turkish_Airlines "Turkish Airlines"). The destinations are mainly European.^[\[227\]](#cite_note-Transavion2-228)^ This airport has superseded the [original Ljubljana airport](/w/index.php?title=Polje_Airport&action=edit&redlink=1 "Polje Airport (page does not exist)"), in operation from 1933 until 1963.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-229)^^[\[229\]](#cite_note-Matjaz2-230)^ It was located in the Municipality of Polje (nowadays the [Moste District](/wiki/Moste,_Ljubljana "Moste, Ljubljana")), on a plain between Ljubljanica and Sava next to the railroad in Moste.^[\[229\]](#cite_note-Matjaz2-230)^ There was a military airport in Šiška from 1918 until 1929.^[\[230\]](#cite_note-ZajecABB2-231)^{#cite_ref-ZajecABB2_231-0}  

### Rail transport {#Rail_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=55 "Edit section: Rail transport")\]

In the [Ljubljana Rail Hub](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Rail_Hub&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana Rail Hub (page does not exist)"), the [Pan-European railway corridors](/wiki/Pan-European_corridors "Pan-European corridors") [V](/w/index.php?title=Pan-European_Corridor_V&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pan-European Corridor V (page does not exist)") (the fastest link between the North Adriatic, and Central and Eastern Europe)^[\[231\]](#cite_note-232)^ and [X](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_X "Pan-European Corridor X") (linking Central Europe with the Balkans)^[\[232\]](#cite_note-233)^ and the [main](/wiki/Main_line_(railway) "Main line (railway)") European lines (E 65, E 69, E 70) intersect.^[\[233\]](#cite_note-234)^ All international transit trains in Slovenia drive through the Ljubljana hub, and all international passenger trains stop there.^[\[234\]](#cite_note-oDPN2010-032-235)^ The area of Ljubljana has six passenger [stations](/wiki/Railway_station "Railway station") and nine stops.^[\[235\]](#cite_note-236)^ For passengers, the [Slovenian Railways](/wiki/Slovenian_Railways "Slovenian Railways") company offers the possibility to buy a daily or monthly city pass that can be used to travel between them.^[\[236\]](#cite_note-237)^ The [Ljubljana railway station](/wiki/Ljubljana_railway_station "Ljubljana railway station") is the central station of the hub. The [Ljubljana Moste Railway Station](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Moste_Railway_Station&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana Moste Railway Station (page does not exist)") is the largest Slovenian railway dispatch. The [Ljubljana Zalog Railway Station](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Zalog_Railway_Station&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana Zalog Railway Station (page does not exist)") is the central Slovenian [rail yard](/wiki/Rail_yard "Rail yard").^[\[234\]](#cite_note-oDPN2010-032-235)^ There are a number of [industrial rails](/wiki/Industrial_railway "Industrial railway") in Ljubljana.^[\[237\]](#cite_note-238)^ At the end of 2006,^[\[238\]](#cite_note-The_Ljubljana_Blog2-239)^ the [Ljubljana Castle funicular](/wiki/Ljubljana_Castle_funicular "Ljubljana Castle funicular") started to operate. The rail goes from [Krek Square](/w/index.php?title=Krek_Square&action=edit&redlink=1 "Krek Square (page does not exist)") (*Krekov trg* ) near the [Ljubljana Central Market](/wiki/Ljubljana_Central_Market "Ljubljana Central Market") to [Ljubljana Castle](/wiki/Ljubljana_Castle "Ljubljana Castle"). It is especially popular among tourists. The full trip lasts 60 seconds.{#cite_ref-The_Ljubljana_Blog2_239-0}  

### Roads {#Roads}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=56 "Edit section: Roads")\]

Ljubljana is located where Slovenia's two main freeways intersect,^[\[239\]](#cite_note-240)^ connecting the freeway route from east to west, in line with [Pan-European Corridor V](/w/index.php?title=Pan-European_Corridor_V&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pan-European Corridor V (page does not exist)"), and the freeway in the north--south direction, in line with [Pan-European Corridor X](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_X "Pan-European Corridor X").^[\[240\]](#cite_note-Oplotnik20042-241)^ The city is linked to the southwest by [A1-E70](/wiki/European_route_E70 "European route E70") to the Italian cities of [Trieste](/wiki/Trieste "Trieste") and [Venice](/wiki/Venice "Venice") and the Croatian port of [Rijeka](/wiki/Rijeka "Rijeka").^[\[241\]](#cite_note-Michelin2-242)^ To the north, [A1-E57](/wiki/European_route_E57 "European route E57") leads to [Maribor](/wiki/Maribor "Maribor"), [Graz](/wiki/Graz "Graz") and [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"). To the east, [A2-E70](/wiki/European_route_E70 "European route E70") links it with the Croatian capital [Zagreb](/wiki/Zagreb "Zagreb"), from where one can go to [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary") or important cities of the former Yugoslavia, such as [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade").^[\[241\]](#cite_note-Michelin2-242)^ To the northwest, [A2-E61](/wiki/European_route_E61 "European route E61") goes to the Austrian towns of [Klagenfurt](/wiki/Klagenfurt "Klagenfurt") and [Salzburg](/wiki/Salzburg "Salzburg"), making it an important entry point for [northern European](/wiki/Northern_Europe "Northern Europe") tourists.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-Michelin2-242)^ A [toll sticker](/wiki/Vignette_(road_tax) "Vignette (road tax)") system has been in use on the [Ljubljana Ring Road](/wiki/Ljubljana_Ring_Road "Ljubljana Ring Road") since 1 July 2008.^[\[242\]](#cite_note-243)^^[\[243\]](#cite_note-244)^ The centre of the city is more difficult to access especially in the peak hours due to long arteries with traffic lights and a large number of daily commuters.^[\[244\]](#cite_note-245)^ The core city centre has been closed for motor traffic since September 2007 (except for residents with permissions), creating a [pedestrian zone](/wiki/Pedestrian_zone "Pedestrian zone") around [Prešeren Square](/wiki/Pre%C5%A1eren_Square "Prešeren Square").^[\[245\]](#cite_note-246)^{#cite_ref-246}  

### Public transport {#Public_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=57 "Edit section: Public transport")\]

The historical [Ljubljana tram system](/wiki/Ljubljana_tram_system "Ljubljana tram system") was completed in 1901 and was replaced by buses in 1928,^[\[246\]](#cite_note-110CPT2-247)^ which were in turn abolished and replaced by trams in 1931^[\[246\]](#cite_note-110CPT2-247)^ with its final length of 18.5 km (11.5 mi) in 1940.^[\[247\]](#cite_note-248)^ In 1959, it was abolished in favor of automobiles;^[\[248\]](#cite_note-Nebec2-249)^ the tracks were dismantled and tram cars were transferred to [Osijek](/wiki/Osijek#Transport "Osijek") and [Subotica](/wiki/Subotica "Subotica").^[\[249\]](#cite_note-250)^ Reintroduction of an actual tram system to Ljubljana has been proposed repeatedly in the 2000s.^[\[250\]](#cite_note-251)^^[\[251\]](#cite_note-252)^{#cite_ref-252}

There are numerous taxi companies in the city.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Mercedes-Benz_O405GN2_LPP_206.jpg/220px-Mercedes-Benz_O405GN2_LPP_206.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mercedes-Benz_O405GN2_LPP_206.jpg) Older type of city bus on the streets of Ljubljana

The [Ljubljana Bus Station](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Bus_Station&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana Bus Station (page does not exist)"), the Ljubljana central bus hub, is located next to the Ljubljana railway station. The city bus network, run by the [Ljubljana Passenger Transport](/wiki/Ljubljana_Passenger_Transport "Ljubljana Passenger Transport") (*LPP* ) company, is Ljubljana's most widely used means of [public transport](/wiki/Public_transport "Public transport"). The fleet is relatively modern. The number of dedicated bus lanes is limited, which can cause problems in peak hours when traffic becomes congested.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-ECORYS20112-253)^ Bus rides may be paid with the [Urbana payment card](/wiki/Urbana_(payment_card) "Urbana (payment card)") (also used for the funicular) or with a [mobile phone](/wiki/Mobile_payment "Mobile payment"). Sometimes the buses are called *trole* (referring to [trolley poles](/wiki/Trolley_pole "Trolley pole")), harking back to the 1951--1971 days when Ljubljana had [trolleybus](/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus") (*trolejbus* ) service.^[\[253\]](#cite_note-Izgubljena2-254)^ There were five [trolleybus lines in Ljubljana](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_trolleybus_system&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana trolleybus system (page does not exist)"), until 1958 alongside the tram.^[\[248\]](#cite_note-Nebec2-249)^{#cite_ref-Nebec2_249-1}

Another means of public road transport in the city centre is the Cavalier (*Kavalir*), an electric [shuttle bus](/wiki/Shuttle_bus "Shuttle bus") vehicle operated by LPP since May 2009. There are three such vehicles in Ljubljana. The ride is free and there are no stations because it can be stopped anywhere. It can carry up to five passengers; most of them are elderly people and tourists.^[\[254\]](#cite_note-255)^ The Cavalier drives in the [car-free zone](/wiki/Car-free_zone "Car-free zone") in the Ljubljana downtown. The first line links [Čop Street](/wiki/%C4%8Cop_Street "Čop Street"), [Wolf Street](/w/index.php?title=Wolf_Street&action=edit&redlink=1 "Wolf Street (page does not exist)") and the [Hribar Embankment](/w/index.php?title=Hribar_Embankment&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hribar Embankment (page does not exist)"), whereas the second links [Town Square](/wiki/Town_Square_(Ljubljana) "Town Square (Ljubljana)"), [Upper Square](/w/index.php?title=Upper_Square_(Ljubljana)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Upper Square (Ljubljana) (page does not exist)"), and [Old Square](/w/index.php?title=Old_Square_(Ljubljana)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Old Square (Ljubljana) (page does not exist)").^[\[255\]](#cite_note-256)^ There is also a [trackless train](/wiki/Trackless_train "Trackless train") (tractor with wagons decorated to look like a train) for tourists in Ljubljana, linking [Cyril and Methodius Square](/w/index.php?title=Cyril_and_Methodius_Square&action=edit&redlink=1 "Cyril and Methodius Square (page does not exist)") in the city centre with Ljubljana Castle.^[\[256\]](#cite_note-257)^{#cite_ref-257}  

### Bicycles {#Bicycles}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=58 "Edit section: Bicycles")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/BicikeLJ_Ljubljana-Pre%C5%A1ernov_trg.JPG/220px-BicikeLJ_Ljubljana-Pre%C5%A1ernov_trg.JPG)](/wiki/File:BicikeLJ_Ljubljana-Pre%C5%A1ernov_trg.JPG) [BicikeLJ](/wiki/BicikeLJ "BicikeLJ"), a Ljubljana-based self-service bicycle network, is free of charge for the first hour.

There is a considerable amount of [bicycle](/wiki/Bicycle "Bicycle") traffic in Ljubljana, especially in the warmer months of the year. It is also possible to rent a bike. Since May 2011, the [BicikeLJ](/wiki/BicikeLJ "BicikeLJ"), a self-service [bicycle rental](/wiki/Bicycle_sharing_system "Bicycle sharing system") system offers the residents and visitors of Ljubljana 600 bicycles and more than 600 parking spots at 60 stations in the wider city centre area. The daily number of rentals is around 2,500.^[\[257\]](#cite_note-258)^^[\[258\]](#cite_note-259)^ There was an option to rent a bike even before the establishment of BicikeLJ.^[\[259\]](#cite_note-Transvelo2-260)^{#cite_ref-Transvelo2_260-0}

There are still some conditions for cyclists in Ljubljana that have been criticised, including cycle lanes in poor condition and constructed in a way that motorised traffic is privileged. There are also many one-way streets which therefore cannot be used as alternate routes so it is difficult to legally travel by bicycle through the city centre.^[\[260\]](#cite_note-261)^^[\[261\]](#cite_note-262)^ Through years, some prohibitions have been partially abolished by marking [cycle lanes](/wiki/Cycle_lane "Cycle lane") on the pavement.^[\[262\]](#cite_note-263)^^[\[263\]](#cite_note-264)^ Nevertheless, the situation has been steadily improving; in 2015, Ljubljana placed 13th in a ranking of the world's most bicycle-friendly cities.^[\[264\]](#cite_note-265)^ In 2016, Ljubljana was 8th on the Copenhagenize list.^[\[265\]](#cite_note-266)^{#cite_ref-266}  

### Water transport {#Water_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=59 "Edit section: Water transport")\]

The river transport on the Ljubljanica and the Sava was the main means of cargo transport to and from the city until the mid-19th century, when railroads were built. Today, the Ljubljanica is used by a number of tourist boats, with wharves under the [Butchers' Bridge](/wiki/Butchers%27_Bridge "Butchers' Bridge"), at [Fish Square](/w/index.php?title=Fish_Square,_Ljubljana&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fish Square, Ljubljana (page does not exist)"), at [Court Square](/w/index.php?title=Court_Square,_Ljubljana&action=edit&redlink=1 "Court Square, Ljubljana (page does not exist)"), at [Breg](/w/index.php?title=Breg,_Ljubljana&action=edit&redlink=1 "Breg, Ljubljana (page does not exist)"), at the [Poljane Embankment](/w/index.php?title=Poljane_Embankment&action=edit&redlink=1 "Poljane Embankment (page does not exist)"), and elsewhere.  

Healthcare {#Healthcare}
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana&action=edit&section=60 "Edit section: Healthcare")\]

Ljubljana has a rich history of discoveries in medicine and innovations in medical technology. The majority of [secondary](/wiki/Secondary_care "Secondary care") and [tertiary care](/wiki/Tertiary_care "Tertiary care") in Slovenia takes place in Ljubljana. The [Ljubljana University Medical Centre](/wiki/Ljubljana_University_Medical_Centre "Ljubljana University Medical Centre") is the largest hospital centre in Slovenia. The [Faculty of Medicine](/w/index.php?title=Faculty_of_Medicine,_Ljubljana&action=edit&redlink=1 "Faculty of Medicine, Ljubljana (page does not exist)") (University of Ljubljana) and the [Ljubljana Institute of Oncology](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Institute_of_Oncology&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana Institute of Oncology (page does not exist)") are the other two central medical institutions in Slovenia. The [Ljubljana Community Health Centre](/w/index.php?title=Ljubljana_Community_Health_Centre&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ljubljana Community Health Centre (page does not exist)") is the largest [health centre](/wiki/Health_centre "Health centre") in Slovenia. It has seven units at 11 locations. Since 1986, Ljubljana is part of the [WHO European Healthy Cities Network](/wiki/Healthy_city "Healthy city").^[\[266\]](#cite_note-267)^{#cite_ref-267}
